Desc: Mode to set for the SEV device.

Name: hardware.cpu.amd.sev.user
Desc: Owner to assign to the SEV device.

Name: hardware.cpu.amd.sevGuest.enable
Desc: Whether to enable access to the AMD SEV guest device.

Name: hardware.cpu.amd.sevGuest.group
Desc: Group to assign to the SEV guest device.

Name: hardware.cpu.amd.sevGuest.mode
Desc: Mode to set for the SEV guest device.

Name: hardware.cpu.amd.sevGuest.user
Desc: Owner to assign to the SEV guest device.

Name: hardware.cpu.amd.updateMicrocode
Desc: Update the CPU microcode for AMD processors.

Name: hardware.cpu.intel.sgx.enableDcapCompat
Desc:
Whether to enable backward compatibility for SGX software build for the
out-of-tree Intel SGX DCAP driver.

Name: hardware.cpu.intel.sgx.provision.enable
Desc: Whether to enable access to the Intel SGX provisioning device.

Name: hardware.cpu.intel.sgx.provision.group
Desc: Group to assign to the SGX provisioning device.

Name: hardware.cpu.intel.sgx.provision.mode
Desc: Mode to set for the SGX provisioning device.

Name: hardware.cpu.intel.sgx.provision.user
Desc: Owner to assign to the SGX provisioning device.

Name: hardware.cpu.intel.updateMicrocode
Desc: Update the CPU microcode for Intel processors.

Name: hardware.cpu.x86.msr.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the <code class="literal">msr

Name: hardware.cpu.x86.msr.group
Desc: Group to set for devices of the <code class="literal">msr

Name: hardware.cpu.x86.msr.mode
Desc: Mode to set for devices of the <code class="literal">msr

Name: hardware.cpu.x86.msr.owner
Desc: Owner to set for devices of the <code class="literal">msr

Name: hardware.cpu.x86.msr.settings
Desc: Parameters for the <code class="literal">msr
Type: attribute set of (boolean or signed integer or string)

Name: hardware.cpu.x86.msr.settings.allow-writes
Desc: Whether to allow writes to MSRs (<code class="literal">"on"

Name: hardware.decklink.enable
Desc: Whether to enable hardware support for the Blackmagic Design Decklink audio/video interfaces.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.enable
Desc:
Build device tree files. These are used to describe the
non-discoverable hardware of a system.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.dtbSource
Desc:
Path to dtb directory that overlays and other processing will be applied to. Uses
device trees bundled with the Linux kernel by default.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.dtboBuildExtraIncludePaths
Desc: Additional include paths that will be passed to the preprocessor when creating the final .dts to compile into .dtbo

Name: hardware.deviceTree.dtboBuildExtraPreprocessorFlags
Desc: Additional flags to pass to the preprocessor during dtbo compilations

Name: hardware.deviceTree.filter
Desc: Only include .dtb files matching glob expression.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.kernelPackage
Desc: Kernel package where device tree include directory is from. Also used as default source of dtb package to apply overlays to

Name: hardware.deviceTree.name
Desc:
The name of an explicit dtb to be loaded, relative to the dtb base.
Useful in extlinux scenarios if the bootloader doesn’t pick the
right .dtb file from FDTDIR.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.overlays
Desc: List of overlays to apply to base device-tree (.dtb) files.
Type: list of ((submodule) or path convertible to it)

Name: hardware.deviceTree.overlays._.dtboFile
Desc: Path to .dtbo compiled overlay file.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.overlays._.dtsFile
Desc:
Path to .dts overlay file, overlay is applied to
each .dtb file matching “compatible” of the overlay.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.overlays._.dtsText
Desc:
Literal DTS contents, overlay is applied to
each .dtb file matching “compatible” of the overlay.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.overlays._.filter
Desc: Only apply to .dtb files matching glob expression.

Name: hardware.deviceTree.overlays._.name
Desc: Name of this overlay

Name: hardware.digitalbitbox.enable
Desc: Enables udev rules for Digital Bitbox devices.

Name: hardware.digitalbitbox.package
Desc: The digitalbitbox package to use. This can be used to install a package with udev rules that differ from the defaults.

Name: hardware.display.edid.enable
Desc: Enables handling of EDID files

Name: hardware.display.edid.packages
Desc: List of packages containing EDID binary files at <code class="literal">$out/lib/firmware/edid

Name: hardware.display.edid.linuxhw
Desc: Exposes EDID files from users-sourced database at https://github.com/linuxhw/EDID
Type: attribute set of list of string

Name: hardware.display.edid.modelines
Desc:
Attribute set of XFree86 Modelines automatically converted
and exposed as <code class="literal">edid/<name>.bin

Name: hardware.display.outputs
Desc: Hardware/kernel-level configuration of specific outputs.

Name: hardware.display.outputs._name_.edid
Desc: An EDID filename to be used for configured display, as in <code class="literal">edid/<filename>

Name: hardware.display.outputs._name_.mode
Desc: A <code class="literal">video

Name: hardware.facetimehd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the facetimehd kernel module.

Name: hardware.facetimehd.withCalibration
Desc:
Whether to include sensor calibration files for facetimehd.
This makes colors look much better but is experimental, see
<a class="link" href="https://github.com/patjak/facetimehd/wiki/Extracting-the-sensor-calibration-files"  target="_top">https://github.com/patjak/facetimehd/wiki/Extracting-the-sensor-calibration-files

Name: hardware.fancontrol.enable
Desc: Whether to enable software fan control (requires fancontrol.config).

Name: hardware.fancontrol.config
Desc: Required fancontrol configuration file content. See <span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">pwmconfig

Name: hardware.firmware
Desc:
List of packages containing firmware files.  Such files
will be loaded automatically if the kernel asks for them
(i.e., when it has detected specific hardware that requires
firmware to function).  If multiple packages contain firmware
files with the same name, the first package in the list takes
precedence.  Note that you must rebuild your system if you add
files to any of these directories.

Name: hardware.flipperzero.enable
Desc: Whether to enable udev rules and software for Flipper Zero devices.

Name: hardware.flirc.enable
Desc: Whether to enable software to configure a Flirc USB device.

Name: hardware.glasgow.enable
Desc:
Enables Glasgow udev rules and ensures ‘plugdev’ group exists.
This is a prerequisite to using Glasgow without being root.

Name: hardware.gpgSmartcards.enable
Desc: Whether to enable udev rules for gnupg smart cards.

Name: hardware.graphics.enable
Desc: Whether to enable hardware accelerated graphics drivers.

Name: hardware.graphics.enable32Bit
Desc:
On 64-bit systems, whether to also install 32-bit drivers for
32-bit applications (such as Wine).

Name: hardware.graphics.extraPackages
Desc:
Additional packages to add to the default graphics driver lookup path.
This can be used to add OpenCL drivers, VA-API/VDPAU drivers, etc.

Name: hardware.graphics.extraPackages32
Desc:
Additional packages to add to 32-bit graphics driver lookup path on 64-bit systems.
Used when <code class="option">enable32Bit

Name: hardware.hackrf.enable
Desc:
Enables hackrf udev rules and ensures ‘plugdev’ group exists.
This is a prerequisite to using HackRF devices without being root, since HackRF USB descriptors will be owned by plugdev through udev.
Ensure your user is a member of the ‘plugdev’ group after enabling.

Name: hardware.i2c.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable i2c devices support. By default access is granted to users in the “i2c”
group (will be created if non-existent) and any user with a seat, meaning
logged on the computer locally
.

Name: hardware.i2c.group
Desc: Grant access to i2c devices (/dev/i2c-*) to users in this group.

Name: hardware.infiniband.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Infiniband support.

Name: hardware.infiniband.guids
Desc: A list of infiniband port guids on the system. This is discoverable using <code class="literal">ibstat -p

Name: hardware.intel-gpu-tools.enable
Desc: Whether to enable a setcap wrapper for intel-gpu-tools.

Name: hardware.ipu6.enable
Desc: Whether to enable support for Intel IPU6/MIPI cameras.

Name: hardware.ipu6.platform
Desc: Choose the version for your hardware platform.

Name: hardware.keyboard.qmk.enable
Desc: Whether to enable non-root access to the firmware of QMK keyboards.

Name: hardware.keyboard.teck.enable
Desc: Whether to enable non-root access to the firmware of TECK keyboards.

Name: hardware.keyboard.uhk.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable non-root access to the firmware of UHK keyboards.
You need it when you want to flash a new firmware on the keyboard.
Access to the keyboard is granted to users in the “input” group.
You may want to install the uhk-agent package
.

Name: hardware.keyboard.zsa.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable udev rules for keyboards from ZSA like the ErgoDox EZ, Planck EZ and Moonlander Mark I.
You need it when you want to flash a new configuration on the keyboard
or use their live training in the browser.
You may want to install the wally-cli package
.

Name: hardware.ksm.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Linux kernel Same-Page Merging.

Name: hardware.ksm.sleep
Desc:
How many milliseconds ksmd should sleep between scans.
Setting it to <code class="literal">null

Name: hardware.ledger.enable
Desc: Whether to enable udev rules for Ledger devices.

Name: hardware.logitech.lcd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable support for Logitech LCD Devices.

Name: hardware.logitech.lcd.devices
Desc: List of USB device ids supported by g15daemon.

Name: hardware.logitech.lcd.startWhenNeeded
Desc: Only run the service when an actual supported device is plugged.

Name: hardware.logitech.wireless.enable
Desc: Whether to enable support for Logitech Wireless Devices.

Name: hardware.logitech.wireless.enableGraphical
Desc: Enable graphical support applications.

Name: hardware.mcelog.enable
Desc: Enable the Machine Check Exception logger.

Name: hardware.mwProCapture.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the Magewell Pro Capture family kernel module.

Name: hardware.new-lg4ff.enable
Desc:
Enables improved Linux module drivers for Logitech driving wheels.
This will replace the existing in-kernel hid-logitech modules.
Works most notably on the Logitech G25, G27, G29 and Driving Force (GT).

Name: hardware.nitrokey.enable
Desc: Enables udev rules for Nitrokey devices.

Name: hardware.nvidia.package
Desc: The NVIDIA driver package to use.

Name: hardware.nvidia.datacenter.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable Data Center drivers for NVIDIA cards on a NVLink topology
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.datacenter.settings
Desc: Additional configuration options for fabricmanager.
Type: attribute set of (atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

Name: hardware.nvidia.dynamicBoost.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable dynamic Boost balances power between the CPU and the GPU for improved
performance on supported laptops using the nvidia-powerd daemon. For more
information, see the NVIDIA docs, on Chapter 23. Dynamic Boost on Linux
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.forceFullCompositionPipeline
Desc:
Whether to enable forcefully the full composition pipeline.
This sometimes fixes screen tearing issues.
This has been reported to reduce the performance of some OpenGL applications and may produce issues in WebGL.
It also drastically increases the time the driver needs to clock down after load
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.gsp.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable the GPU System Processor (GSP) on the video card
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.modesetting.enable
Desc: Whether to enable kernel modesetting when using the NVIDIA proprietary driver.

Name: hardware.nvidia.nvidiaPersistenced
Desc:
Whether to enable nvidia-persistenced a update for NVIDIA GPU headless mode, i.e.
It ensures all GPUs stay awake even during headless mode
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.nvidiaSettings
Desc:
Whether to enable nvidia-settings, NVIDIA’s GUI configuration tool
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.open
Desc: Whether to enable the open source NVIDIA kernel module.

Name: hardware.nvidia.powerManagement.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable experimental power management through systemd. For more information, see
the NVIDIA docs, on Chapter 21. Configuring Power Management Support
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.powerManagement.finegrained
Desc:
Whether to enable experimental power management of PRIME offload. For more information, see
the NVIDIA docs, on Chapter 22. PCI-Express Runtime D3 (RTD3) Power Management
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.allowExternalGpu
Desc:
Whether to enable configuring X to allow external NVIDIA GPUs when using Prime [Reverse] sync optimus
.

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.amdgpuBusId
Desc:
Bus ID of the AMD APU. You can find it using lspci; for example if lspci
shows the AMD APU at “04:00.0”, set this option to “PCI:4:0:0”.

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.intelBusId
Desc:
Bus ID of the Intel GPU. You can find it using lspci; for example if lspci
shows the Intel GPU at “00:02.0”, set this option to “PCI:0:2:0”.

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.nvidiaBusId
Desc:
Bus ID of the NVIDIA GPU. You can find it using lspci; for example if lspci
shows the NVIDIA GPU at “01:00.0”, set this option to “PCI:1:0:0”.

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.offload.enable
Desc: Whether to enable render offload support using the NVIDIA proprietary driver via PRIME.

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.offload.enableOffloadCmd
Desc: Whether to enable adding a <code class="literal">nvidia-offload

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.reverseSync.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable NVIDIA Optimus support using the NVIDIA proprietary driver via reverse
PRIME. If enabled, the Intel/AMD GPU will be used for all rendering, while
enabling output to displays attached only to the NVIDIA GPU without a
multiplexer.

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.reverseSync.setupCommands.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable configure the display manager to be able to use the outputs
attached to the NVIDIA GPU.
Disable in order to configure the NVIDIA GPU outputs manually using xrandr.
Note that this configuration will only be successful when a display manager
for which the <code class="option">services.xserver.displayManager.setupCommands

Name: hardware.nvidia.prime.sync.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable NVIDIA Optimus support using the NVIDIA proprietary driver via PRIME.
If enabled, the NVIDIA GPU will be always on and used for all rendering,
while enabling output to displays attached only to the integrated Intel/AMD
GPU without a multiplexer.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.enable
Desc:
Enable dynamic CDI configuration for Nvidia devices by running
nvidia-container-toolkit on boot.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.package
Desc: The nvidia-container-toolkit package to use.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.device-name-strategy
Desc:
Specify the strategy for generating device names,
passed to <code class="literal">nvidia-ctk cdi generate

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.mount-nvidia-docker-1-directories
Desc:
Mount nvidia-docker-1 directories on containers: /usr/local/nvidia/lib and
/usr/local/nvidia/lib64.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.mount-nvidia-executables
Desc:
Mount executables nvidia-smi, nvidia-cuda-mps-control, nvidia-cuda-mps-server,
nvidia-debugdump, nvidia-powerd and nvidia-ctk on containers.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.mounts
Desc: Mounts to be added to every container under the Nvidia CDI profile.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.mounts._.containerPath
Desc: Container path.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.mounts._.hostPath
Desc: Host path.

Name: hardware.nvidia-container-toolkit.mounts._.mountOptions
Desc: Mount options.

Name: hardware.nvidiaOptimus.disable
Desc:
Completely disable the NVIDIA graphics card and use the
integrated graphics processor instead.

Name: hardware.onlykey.enable
Desc: Enable OnlyKey device (https://crp.to/p/) support.

Name: hardware.openrazer.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable OpenRazer drivers and userspace daemon
.

Name: hardware.openrazer.batteryNotifier
Desc: Settings for device battery notifications.

Name: hardware.openrazer.batteryNotifier.enable
Desc: Mouse battery notifier.

Name: hardware.openrazer.batteryNotifier.frequency
Desc:
How often battery notifications should be shown (in seconds).
A value of 0 disables notifications.

Name: hardware.openrazer.batteryNotifier.percentage
Desc:
At what battery percentage the device should reach before
sending notifications.

Name: hardware.openrazer.devicesOffOnScreensaver
Desc: Turn off the devices when the systems screensaver kicks in.

Name: hardware.openrazer.keyStatistics
Desc:
Collects number of keypresses per hour per key used to
generate a heatmap.

Name: hardware.openrazer.syncEffectsEnabled
Desc:
Set the sync effects flag to true so any assignment of
effects will work across devices.

Name: hardware.openrazer.users
Desc:
Usernames to be added to the “openrazer” group, so that they
can start and interact with the OpenRazer userspace daemon.

Name: hardware.openrazer.verboseLogging
Desc: Whether to enable verbose logging. Logs debug messages.

Name: hardware.opentabletdriver.enable
Desc:
Enable OpenTabletDriver udev rules, user service and blacklist kernel
modules known to conflict with OpenTabletDriver.

Name: hardware.opentabletdriver.package
Desc: The opentabletdriver package to use.

Name: hardware.opentabletdriver.blacklistedKernelModules
Desc: Blacklist of kernel modules known to conflict with OpenTabletDriver.

Name: hardware.opentabletdriver.daemon.enable
Desc: Whether to start OpenTabletDriver daemon as a systemd user service.

Name: hardware.parallels.enable
Desc:
This enables Parallels Tools for Linux guests, along with provided
video, mouse and other hardware drivers.

Name: hardware.parallels.package
Desc: Defines which package to use for prl-tools. Override to change the version.

Name: hardware.pcmcia.enable
Desc: Enable this option to support PCMCIA card.

Name: hardware.pcmcia.config
Desc:
Path to the configuration file which maps the memory, IRQs
and ports used by the PCMCIA hardware.

Name: hardware.pcmcia.firmware
Desc: List of firmware used to handle specific PCMCIA card.

Name: hardware.printers.ensureDefaultPrinter
Desc: Ensures the named printer is the default CUPS printer / printer queue.
Type: null or printable string without spaces, # and /

Name: hardware.printers.ensurePrinters
Desc:
Will regularly ensure that the given CUPS printers are configured as declared here.
If a printer’s options are manually changed afterwards, they will be overwritten eventually.
This option will never delete any printer, even if removed from this list.
You can check existing printers with <span class="command"><strong>lpstat -s

Name: hardware.printers.ensurePrinters._.description
Desc: Optional human-readable description.

Name: hardware.printers.ensurePrinters._.deviceUri
Desc:
How to reach the printer.
<span class="command"><strong>lpinfo -v

Name: hardware.printers.ensurePrinters._.location
Desc: Optional human-readable location.

Name: hardware.printers.ensurePrinters._.model
Desc:
Location of the ppd driver file for the printer.
<span class="command"><strong>lpinfo -m

Name: hardware.printers.ensurePrinters._.name
Desc:
Name of the printer / printer queue.
May contain any printable characters except “/”, “#”, and space.

Name: hardware.printers.ensurePrinters._.ppdOptions
Desc:
Sets PPD options for the printer.
<span class="command"><strong>lpoptions [-p printername] -l

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the PulseAudio sound server.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.package
Desc:
The PulseAudio derivation to use.  This can be used to enable
features (such as JACK support, Bluetooth) via the
<code class="literal">pulseaudioFull

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.configFile
Desc:
The path to the default configuration options the PulseAudio server
should use. By default, the “default.pa” configuration
from the PulseAudio distribution is used.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.daemon.config
Desc: Config of the pulse daemon. See <code class="literal">man pulse-daemon.conf

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.daemon.logLevel
Desc:
The log level that the system-wide pulseaudio daemon should use,
if activated.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.extraClientConf
Desc: Extra configuration appended to pulse/client.conf file.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.extraConfig
Desc: Literal string to append to <code class="literal">configFile

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.extraModules
Desc:
Extra pulseaudio modules to use. This is intended for out-of-tree
pulseaudio modules like extra bluetooth codecs.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.support32Bit
Desc:
Whether to include the 32-bit pulseaudio libraries in the system or not.
This is only useful on 64-bit systems and currently limited to x86_64-linux.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.systemWide
Desc:
If false, a PulseAudio server is launched automatically for
each user that tries to use the sound system. The server runs
with user privileges. If true, one system-wide PulseAudio
server is launched on boot, running as the user “pulse”, and
only users in the “pulse-access” group will have access to the server.
Please read the PulseAudio documentation for more details.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.tcp.enable
Desc: Whether to enable tcp streaming support.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.tcp.anonymousClients.allowAll
Desc: Whether to enable all anonymous clients to stream to the server.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.tcp.anonymousClients.allowedIpRanges
Desc: A list of IP subnets that are allowed to stream to the server.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.zeroconf.discovery.enable
Desc: Whether to enable discovery of pulseaudio sinks in the local network.

Name: hardware.pulseaudio.zeroconf.publish.enable
Desc: Whether to enable publishing the pulseaudio sink in the local network.

Name: hardware.raid.HPSmartArray.enable
Desc: Whether to enable HP Smart Array kernel modules and CLI utility.

Name: hardware.rasdaemon.enable
Desc: Whether to enable RAS logging daemon.

Name: hardware.rasdaemon.config
Desc:
rasdaemon configuration, currently only used for CE PFA
for details, read rasdaemon.outPath/etc/sysconfig/rasdaemon’s comments

Name: hardware.rasdaemon.extraModules
Desc: extra kernel modules to load

Name: hardware.rasdaemon.labels
Desc: Additional memory module label descriptions to be placed in /etc/ras/dimm_labels.d/labels

Name: hardware.rasdaemon.mainboard
Desc: Custom mainboard description, see <span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">ras-mc-ctl

Name: hardware.rasdaemon.record
Desc: record events via sqlite3, required for ras-mc-ctl

Name: hardware.rasdaemon.testing
Desc: Whether to enable error injection infrastructure.

Name: hardware.rtl-sdr.enable
Desc:
Enables rtl-sdr udev rules, ensures ‘plugdev’ group exists, and blacklists DVB kernel modules.
This is a prerequisite to using devices supported by rtl-sdr without being root, since rtl-sdr USB descriptors will be owned by plugdev through udev.

Name: hardware.saleae-logic.enable
Desc: Whether to enable udev rules for Saleae Logic devices.

Name: hardware.saleae-logic.package
Desc: Saleae Logic package to use.

Name: hardware.sane.enable
Desc: Enable support for SANE scanners.

Name: hardware.sane.backends-package
Desc: Backends driver package to use.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan4.enable
Desc:
When enabled, will automatically register the “brscan4” sane
backend and bring configuration files to their expected location.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan4.netDevices
Desc:
The list of network devices that will be registered against the brscan4
sane backend.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan4.netDevices._name_.ip
Desc:
The ip address of the device. If undefined, you will have to
provide a nodename.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan4.netDevices._name_.model
Desc: The model of the network device.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan4.netDevices._name_.name
Desc:
The friendly name you give to the network device. If undefined,
the name of attribute will be used.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan4.netDevices._name_.nodename
Desc:
The node name of the device. If undefined, you will have to
provide an ip.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan5.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the Brother brscan5 sane backend.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan5.netDevices
Desc:
The list of network devices that will be registered against the brscan5
sane backend.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan5.netDevices._name_.ip
Desc:
The ip address of the device. If undefined, you will have to
provide a nodename.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan5.netDevices._name_.model
Desc: The model of the network device.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan5.netDevices._name_.name
Desc:
The friendly name you give to the network device. If undefined,
the name of attribute will be used.

Name: hardware.sane.brscan5.netDevices._name_.nodename
Desc:
The node name of the device. If undefined, you will have to
provide an ip.

Name: hardware.sane.disabledDefaultBackends
Desc:
Names of backends which are enabled by default but should be disabled.
See <code class="literal">$SANE_CONFIG_DIR/dll.conf

Name: hardware.sane.drivers.scanSnap.enable
Desc: Whether to enable drivers for the Fujitsu ScanSnap scanners.

Name: hardware.sane.drivers.scanSnap.package
Desc: The epjitsu package to use. Useful if you want to extract the driver files yourself.

Name: hardware.sane.dsseries.enable
Desc: When enabled, will automatically register the “dsseries” SANE backend.

Name: hardware.sane.extraBackends
Desc: Packages providing extra SANE backends to enable.

Name: hardware.sane.netConf
Desc: Network hosts that should be probed for remote scanners.

Name: hardware.sane.openFirewall
Desc:
Open ports needed for discovery of scanners on the local network, e.g.
needed for Canon scanners (BJNP protocol).

Name: hardware.sane.snapshot
Desc: Use a development snapshot of SANE scanner drivers.

Name: hardware.sata.timeout.enable
Desc: Whether to enable SATA drive timeouts.

Name: hardware.sata.timeout.deciSeconds
Desc: Set SCT Error Recovery Control timeout in deciseconds for use in RAID configurations.

Name: hardware.sata.timeout.drives
Desc: List of drives for which to configure the timeout.

Name: hardware.sata.timeout.drives._.idBy
Desc: The method to identify the drive.

Name: hardware.sata.timeout.drives._.name
Desc: Drive name without the full path.

Name: hardware.sensor.hddtemp.enable
Desc: Enable this option to support HDD/SSD temperature sensors.

Name: hardware.sensor.hddtemp.dbEntries
Desc: Additional DB entries

Name: hardware.sensor.hddtemp.drives
Desc: List of drives to monitor. If you pass /dev/disk/by-path/* entries the symlinks will be resolved as hddtemp doesn’t like names with colons.

Name: hardware.sensor.hddtemp.extraArgs
Desc: Additional arguments passed to the daemon.

Name: hardware.sensor.hddtemp.unit
Desc: Celsius or Fahrenheit

Name: hardware.sensor.iio.enable
Desc: Enable this option to support IIO sensors with iio-sensor-proxy.

Name: hardware.spacenavd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable spacenavd to support 3DConnexion devices.

Name: hardware.steam-hardware.enable
Desc: Enable udev rules for Steam hardware such as the Steam Controller, other supported controllers and the HTC Vive

Name: hardware.system76.enableAll
Desc: Whether to enable all recommended configuration for system76 systems.

Name: hardware.system76.firmware-daemon.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the system76 firmware daemon

Name: hardware.system76.kernel-modules.enable
Desc: Whether to make the system76 out-of-tree kernel modules available

Name: hardware.system76.power-daemon.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the system76 power daemon

Name: hardware.trackpoint.enable
Desc: Enable sensitivity and speed configuration for trackpoints.

Name: hardware.trackpoint.device
Desc:
The device name of the trackpoint. You can check with xinput.
Some newer devices (example x1c6) use “TPPS/2 Elan TrackPoint”.

Name: hardware.trackpoint.emulateWheel
Desc: Enable scrolling while holding the middle mouse button.

Name: hardware.trackpoint.fakeButtons
Desc:
Switch to “bare” PS/2 mouse support in case Trackpoint buttons are not recognized
properly. This can happen for example on models like the L430, T450, T450s, on
which the Trackpoint buttons are actually a part of the Synaptics touchpad.

Name: hardware.trackpoint.sensitivity
Desc:
Configure the trackpoint sensitivity. By default, the kernel
configures 128.

Name: hardware.trackpoint.speed
Desc:
Configure the trackpoint speed. By default, the kernel
configures 97.

Name: hardware.tuxedo-drivers.enable
Desc: Whether to enable The tuxedo-drivers driver enables access to the following on TUXEDO notebooks:

Name: hardware.tuxedo-rs.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Rust utilities for interacting with hardware from TUXEDO Computers.

Name: hardware.tuxedo-rs.tailor-gui.enable
Desc: Whether to enable tailor-gui, an alternative to TUXEDO Control Center, written in Rust.

Name: hardware.ubertooth.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Ubertooth software and its udev rules.

Name: hardware.ubertooth.group
Desc: Group for Ubertooth’s udev rules.

Name: hardware.uinput.enable
Desc: Whether to enable uinput support.

Name: hardware.uni-sync.enable
Desc: Whether to enable udev rules and software for Lian Li Uni Controllers.

Name: hardware.uni-sync.package
Desc: The uni-sync package to use.

Name: hardware.uni-sync.devices
Desc: List of controllers with their configurations.

Name: hardware.uni-sync.devices._.channels
Desc: List of channels connected to the controller.

Name: hardware.uni-sync.devices._.channels._.mode
Desc: “PWM” to enable PWM sync. “Manual” to set speed.

Name: hardware.uni-sync.devices._.channels._.speed
Desc: Fan speed as percentage (clamped between 0 and 100).

Name: hardware.uni-sync.devices._.device_id
Desc: Unique device ID displayed at each startup.

Name: hardware.uni-sync.devices._.sync_rgb
Desc: Enable ARGB header sync.

Name: hardware.usb-modeswitch.enable
Desc: Enable this option to support certain USB WLAN and WWAN adapters.

Name: hardware.usbStorage.manageShutdown
Desc:
Enable this option to gracefully spin-down external storage during shutdown.
If you suspect improper head parking after poweroff, install <code class="literal">smartmontools

Name: hardware.wirelessRegulatoryDatabase
Desc: Whether to enable loading the wireless regulatory database at boot.

Name: hardware.wooting.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable support for Wooting keyboards.
Note that users must be in the “input” group for udev rules to apply.

Name: hardware.xone.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the xone driver for Xbox One and Xbox Series X|S accessories.

Name: hardware.xpadneo.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the xpadneo driver for Xbox One wireless controllers.

Name: i18n.defaultLocale
Desc:
The default locale.  It determines the language for program
messages, the format for dates and times, sort order, and so on.
It also determines the character set, such as UTF-8.

Name: i18n.extraLocaleSettings
Desc:
A set of additional system-wide locale settings other than
<code class="literal">LANG

Name: i18n.glibcLocales
Desc: Customized pkg.glibcLocales package.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.enable
Desc: Whether to enable an additional input method type.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.enabled
Desc: Deprecated - use <code class="literal">type

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.addons
Desc: Enabled Fcitx5 addons.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.ignoreUserConfig
Desc: Ignore the user configures. <span class="strong"><strong>Warning

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.plasma6Support
Desc:
Use qt6 versions of fcitx5 packages.
Required for configuring fcitx5 in KDE System Settings.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.quickPhrase
Desc: Quick phrases.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.quickPhraseFiles
Desc: Quick phrase files.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.settings.addons
Desc: The addon configures in <code class="literal">conf

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.settings.globalOptions
Desc: The global options in <code class="literal">config
Type: attribute set of section of an INI file (attrs of INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.settings.inputMethod
Desc: The input method configure in <code class="literal">profile
Type: attribute set of section of an INI file (attrs of INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

Name: i18n.inputMethod.fcitx5.waylandFrontend
Desc:
Use the Wayland input method frontend.
See <a class="link" href="https://fcitx-im.org/wiki/Using_Fcitx_5_on_Wayland"  target="_top">Using Fcitx 5 on Wayland

Name: i18n.inputMethod.ibus.engines
Desc: Enabled IBus engines. Available engines are: <code class="literal">anthy

Name: i18n.inputMethod.ibus.panel
Desc: Replace the IBus panel with another panel.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.kime.daemonModules
Desc: List of enabled daemon modules

Name: i18n.inputMethod.kime.extraConfig
Desc: extra kime configuration. Refer to <a class="link" href="https://github.com/Riey/kime/blob/v3.1.1/docs/CONFIGURATION.md"  target="_top">https://github.com/Riey/kime/blob/v3.1.1/docs/CONFIGURATION.md

Name: i18n.inputMethod.kime.iconColor
Desc: Color of the indicator icon

Name: i18n.inputMethod.type
Desc: Select the enabled input method. Input methods is a software to input symbols that are not available on standard input devices.

Name: i18n.inputMethod.uim.toolbar
Desc: selected UIM toolbar.

Name: i18n.supportedLocales
Desc:
List of locales that the system should support.  The value
<code class="literal">"all"

Name: image.modules
Desc: image-specific NixOS Modules used for <code class="literal">system.build.images
Type: attribute set of list of module

Name: image.repart.package
Desc: The systemd-repart package to use.

Name: image.repart.compression.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Image compression.

Name: image.repart.compression.algorithm
Desc: Compression algorithm

Name: image.repart.compression.level
Desc: Compression level. The available range depends on the used algorithm.

Name: image.repart.imageFile
Desc: Filename of the image including all extensions (e.g <code class="literal">image_1.raw

Name: image.repart.imageFileBasename
Desc: Basename of the image filename without any extension (e.g. <code class="literal">image_1

Name: image.repart.mkfsOptions
Type: attribute set of list of string

Name: image.repart.name
Desc: Name of the image.

Name: image.repart.partitions
Desc:
Specify partitions as a set of the names of the partitions with their
configuration as the key.

Name: image.repart.partitions._name_.contents
Desc: The contents to end up in the filesystem image.

Name: image.repart.partitions._name_.contents._name_.source
Desc: Path of the source file.

Name: image.repart.partitions._name_.repartConfig
Desc:
Specify the repart options for a partiton as a structural setting.
See <a class="link" href="https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/repart.d.html"  target="_top">https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/repart.d.html
Type: attribute set of (string or signed integer or boolean)

Name: image.repart.partitions._name_.storePaths
Desc: The store paths to include in the partition.

Name: image.repart.partitions._name_.stripNixStorePrefix
Desc: Whether to strip <code class="literal">/nix/store/

Name: image.repart.sectorSize
Desc:
The sector size of the disk image produced by systemd-repart. This
value must be a power of 2 between 512 and 4096.

Name: image.repart.seed
Desc: A UUID to use as a seed. You can set this to <code class="literal">null

Name: image.repart.split
Desc:
Enables generation of split artifacts from partitions. If enabled, for
each partition with SplitName= set, a separate output file containing
just the contents of that partition is generated.

Name: image.repart.verityStore.enable
Desc: Whether to enable building images with a dm-verity protected nix store.

Name: image.repart.verityStore.partitionIds.esp
Desc: Specify the attribute name of the ESP.

Name: image.repart.verityStore.partitionIds.store
Desc: Specify the attribute name of the store partition.

Name: image.repart.verityStore.partitionIds.store-verity
Desc: Specify the attribute name of the store’s dm-verity hash partition.

Name: image.repart.verityStore.ukiPath
Desc: Specify the location on the ESP where the UKI is placed.

Name: image.repart.version
Desc: Version of the image

Name: lib
Desc: This option allows modules to define helper functions, constants, etc.

Name: location.latitude
Desc:
Your current latitude, between
<code class="literal">-90.0

Name: location.longitude
Desc:
Your current longitude, between
between <code class="literal">-180.0

Name: location.provider
Desc:
The location provider to use for determining your location. If set to
<code class="literal">manual

Name: networking.enableB43Firmware
Desc: Turn on this option if you want firmware for the NICs supported by the b43 module.

Name: networking.enableIPv6
Desc: Whether to enable support for IPv6.

Name: networking.enableIntel2200BGFirmware
Desc:
Turn on this option if you want firmware for the Intel
PRO/Wireless 2200BG to be loaded automatically.  This is
required if you want to use this device.

Name: networking.bonds
Desc:
This option allows you to define bond devices that aggregate multiple,
underlying networking interfaces together. The value of this option is
an attribute set. Each attribute specifies a bond, with the attribute
name specifying the name of the bond’s network interface

Name: networking.bonds._name_.driverOptions
Desc:
Options for the bonding driver.
Documentation can be found in
<a class="link" href="https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/bonding.txt"  target="_top">https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/bonding.txt

Name: networking.bonds._name_.interfaces
Desc: The interfaces to bond together

Name: networking.bonds._name_.lacp_rate
Desc: DEPRECATED, use <code class="literal">driverOptions

Name: networking.bonds._name_.miimon
Desc: DEPRECATED, use <code class="literal">driverOptions

Name: networking.bonds._name_.mode
Desc: DEPRECATED, use <code class="literal">driverOptions

Name: networking.bonds._name_.xmit_hash_policy
Desc: DEPRECATED, use <code class="literal">driverOptions

Name: networking.bridges
Desc:
This option allows you to define Ethernet bridge devices
that connect physical networks together.  The value of this
option is an attribute set.  Each attribute specifies a
bridge, with the attribute name specifying the name of the
bridge’s network interface.

Name: networking.bridges._name_.interfaces
Desc: The physical network interfaces connected by the bridge.

Name: networking.bridges._name_.rstp
Desc: Whether the bridge interface should enable rstp.

Name: networking.defaultGateway
Desc:
The default gateway. It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.
It can be specified as a string or an option set along with a network interface.
Type: null or ((submodule) or string convertible to it)

Name: networking.defaultGateway.address
Desc: The default gateway address.

Name: networking.defaultGateway.interface
Desc: The default gateway interface.

Name: networking.defaultGateway.metric
Desc: The default gateway metric/preference.

Name: networking.defaultGateway6
Desc:
The default ipv6 gateway. It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.
It can be specified as a string or an option set along with a network interface.
Type: null or ((submodule) or string convertible to it)

Name: networking.defaultGateway6.address
Desc: The default gateway address.

Name: networking.defaultGateway6.interface
Desc: The default gateway interface.

Name: networking.defaultGateway6.metric
Desc: The default gateway metric/preference.

Name: networking.defaultGatewayWindowSize
Desc:
The window size of the default gateway. It limits maximal data bursts that TCP peers
are allowed to send to us.

Name: networking.dhcpcd.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable dhcpcd for device configuration. This is mainly to
explicitly disable dhcpcd (for example when using networkd).

Name: networking.dhcpcd.IPv6rs
Desc:
Force enable or disable solicitation and receipt of IPv6 Router Advertisements.
This is required, for example, when using a static unique local IPv6 address (ULA)
and global IPv6 address auto-configuration with SLAAC.

Name: networking.dhcpcd.allowInterfaces
Desc:
Enable the DHCP client for any interface whose name matches
any of the shell glob patterns in this list. Any interface not
explicitly matched by this pattern will be denied. This pattern only
applies when non-null.

Name: networking.dhcpcd.denyInterfaces
Desc:
Disable the DHCP client for any interface whose name matches
any of the shell glob patterns in this list. The purpose of
this option is to blacklist virtual interfaces such as those
created by Xen, libvirt, LXC, etc.

Name: networking.dhcpcd.extraConfig
Desc: Literal string to append to the config file generated for dhcpcd.

Name: networking.dhcpcd.persistent
Desc:
Whenever to leave interfaces configured on dhcpcd daemon
shutdown. Set to true if you have your root or store mounted
over the network or this machine accepts SSH connections
through DHCP interfaces and clients should be notified when
it shuts down.

Name: networking.dhcpcd.runHook
Desc:
Shell code that will be run after all other hooks. See
<code class="literal">man dhcpcd-run-hooks

Name: networking.dhcpcd.wait
Desc:
This option specifies when the dhcpcd service will fork to background.
If set to “background”, dhcpcd will fork to background immediately.
If set to “ipv4” or “ipv6”, dhcpcd will wait for the corresponding IP
address to be assigned. If set to “any”, dhcpcd will wait for any type
(IPv4 or IPv6) to be assigned. If set to “both”, dhcpcd will wait for
both an IPv4 and an IPv6 address before forking.
The option “if-carrier-up” is equivalent to “any” if either ethernet
is plugged nor WiFi is powered, and to “background” otherwise.

Name: networking.domain
Desc: The domain.  It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.

Name: networking.extraHosts
Desc: Additional verbatim entries to be appended to <code class="filename">/etc/hosts

Name: networking.firewall.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable the firewall.  This is a simple stateful
firewall that blocks connection attempts to unauthorised TCP
or UDP ports on this machine.

Name: networking.firewall.package
Desc: The package to use for running the firewall service.

Name: networking.firewall.allowPing
Desc:
Whether to respond to incoming ICMPv4 echo requests
(“pings”).  ICMPv6 pings are always allowed because the
larger address space of IPv6 makes network scanning much
less effective.

Name: networking.firewall.allowedTCPPortRanges
Desc:
A range of TCP ports on which incoming connections are
accepted.
Type: list of attribute set of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts
Desc:
List of TCP ports on which incoming connections are
accepted.
Type: list of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.allowedUDPPortRanges
Desc: Range of open UDP ports.
Type: list of attribute set of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.allowedUDPPorts
Desc: List of open UDP ports.
Type: list of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.autoLoadConntrackHelpers
Desc:
Whether to auto-load connection-tracking helpers.
See the description at networking.firewall.connectionTrackingModules

Name: networking.firewall.checkReversePath
Desc:
Performs a reverse path filter test on a packet.  If a reply
to the packet would not be sent via the same interface that
the packet arrived on, it is refused.

Name: networking.firewall.connectionTrackingModules
Desc:
List of connection-tracking helpers that are auto-loaded.
The complete list of possible values is given in the example.

Name: networking.firewall.extraCommands
Desc:
Additional shell commands executed as part of the firewall
initialisation script.  These are executed just before the
final “reject” firewall rule is added, so they can be used
to allow packets that would otherwise be refused.

Name: networking.firewall.extraForwardRules
Desc:
Additional nftables rules to be appended to the forward-allow
chain.

Name: networking.firewall.extraInputRules
Desc:
Additional nftables rules to be appended to the input-allow
chain.

Name: networking.firewall.extraPackages
Desc:
Additional packages to be included in the environment of the system
as well as the path of networking.firewall.extraCommands.

Name: networking.firewall.extraReversePathFilterRules
Desc:
Additional nftables rules to be appended to the rpfilter-allow
chain.

Name: networking.firewall.extraStopCommands
Desc:
Additional shell commands executed as part of the firewall
shutdown script.  These are executed just after the removal
of the NixOS input rule, or if the service enters a failed
state.

Name: networking.firewall.filterForward
Desc: Enable filtering in IP forwarding.

Name: networking.firewall.interfaces
Desc: Interface-specific open ports.

Name: networking.firewall.interfaces._name_.allowedTCPPortRanges
Desc:
A range of TCP ports on which incoming connections are
accepted.
Type: list of attribute set of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.interfaces._name_.allowedTCPPorts
Desc:
List of TCP ports on which incoming connections are
accepted.
Type: list of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.interfaces._name_.allowedUDPPortRanges
Desc: Range of open UDP ports.
Type: list of attribute set of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.interfaces._name_.allowedUDPPorts
Desc: List of open UDP ports.
Type: list of 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.firewall.logRefusedConnections
Desc:
Whether to log rejected or dropped incoming connections.
Note: The logs are found in the kernel logs, i.e. dmesg
or journalctl -k.

Name: networking.firewall.logRefusedPackets
Desc:
Whether to log all rejected or dropped incoming packets.
This tends to give a lot of log messages, so it’s mostly
useful for debugging.
Note: The logs are found in the kernel logs, i.e. dmesg
or journalctl -k.

Name: networking.firewall.logRefusedUnicastsOnly
Desc: If <code class="option">networking.firewall.logRefusedPackets

Name: networking.firewall.logReversePathDrops
Desc:
Logs dropped packets failing the reverse path filter test if
the option networking.firewall.checkReversePath is enabled.

Name: networking.firewall.pingLimit
Desc: If pings are allowed, this allows setting rate limits on them.

Name: networking.firewall.rejectPackets
Desc:
If set, refused packets are rejected rather than dropped
(ignored).  This means that an ICMP “port unreachable” error
message is sent back to the client (or a TCP RST packet in
case of an existing connection).  Rejecting packets makes
port scanning somewhat easier.

Name: networking.firewall.trustedInterfaces
Desc:
Traffic coming in from these interfaces will be accepted
unconditionally.  Traffic from the loopback (lo) interface
will always be accepted.

Name: networking.fooOverUDP
Desc:
This option allows you to configure Foo Over UDP and Generic UDP Encapsulation
endpoints. See <span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">ip-fou

Name: networking.fooOverUDP._name_.local
Desc: Local address (and optionally device) to bind to using the given port.

Name: networking.fooOverUDP._name_.local.address
Desc:
Local address to bind to. The address must be available when the FOU
endpoint is created, using the scripted network setup this can be achieved
either by setting <code class="literal">dev

Name: networking.fooOverUDP._name_.local.dev
Desc: Network device to bind to.

Name: networking.fooOverUDP._name_.port
Desc: Local port of the encapsulation UDP socket.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.fooOverUDP._name_.protocol
Desc: Protocol number of the encapsulated packets. Specifying <code class="literal">null
Type: null or integer between 1 and 255 (both inclusive)

Name: networking.fqdn
Desc:
The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of this host. It is the result
of combining <code class="literal">networking.hostName

Name: networking.fqdnOrHostName
Desc:
Either the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or just the host name if
it does not exists.

Name: networking.greTunnels
Desc: This option allows you to define Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) tunnels.

Name: networking.greTunnels._name_.dev
Desc: The underlying network device on which the tunnel resides.

Name: networking.greTunnels._name_.local
Desc:
The address of the local endpoint which the remote
side should send packets to.

Name: networking.greTunnels._name_.remote
Desc: The address of the remote endpoint to forward traffic over.

Name: networking.greTunnels._name_.ttl
Desc: The time-to-live/hoplimit of the connection to the remote tunnel endpoint.

Name: networking.greTunnels._name_.type
Desc: Whether the tunnel routes layer 2 (tap) or layer 3 (tun) traffic.

Name: networking.hostFiles
Desc: Files that should be concatenated together to form <code class="filename">/etc/hosts

Name: networking.hostId
Desc: The 32-bit host ID of the machine, formatted as 8 hexadecimal characters.

Name: networking.hostName
Desc:
The name of the machine. Leave it empty if you want to obtain it from a
DHCP server (if using DHCP). The hostname must be a valid DNS label (see
RFC 1035 section 2.3.1: “Preferred name syntax”, RFC 1123 section 2.1:
“Host Names and Numbers”) and as such must not contain the domain part.
This means that the hostname must start with a letter or digit,
end with a letter or digit, and have as interior characters only
letters, digits, and hyphen. The maximum length is 63 characters.
Additionally it is recommended to only use lower-case characters.
If (e.g. for legacy reasons) a FQDN is required as the Linux kernel
network node hostname (uname --nodename) the option
boot.kernel.sysctl.“kernel.hostname” can be used as a workaround (but
the 64 character limit still applies).

Name: networking.hosts
Desc: Locally defined maps of hostnames to IP addresses.
Type: attribute set of list of string

Name: networking.interfaces
Desc: The configuration for each network interface.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.addresses
Desc: List of IPv4 addresses that will be statically assigned to the interface.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.addresses._.address
Desc:
IPv4 address of the interface. Leave empty to configure the
interface using DHCP.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.addresses._.prefixLength
Desc:
Subnet mask of the interface, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<code class="literal">24

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.routes
Desc: List of extra IPv4 static routes that will be assigned to the interface.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.routes._.address
Desc: IPv4 address of the network.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.routes._.options
Desc: Other route options. See the symbol <code class="literal">OPTIONS

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.routes._.prefixLength
Desc:
Subnet mask of the network, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<code class="literal">24

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.routes._.type
Desc: Type of the route.  See the <code class="literal">Route types

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv4.routes._.via
Desc: IPv4 address of the next hop.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.addresses
Desc: List of IPv6 addresses that will be statically assigned to the interface.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.addresses._.address
Desc:
IPv6 address of the interface. Leave empty to configure the
interface using DHCP.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.addresses._.prefixLength
Desc:
Subnet mask of the interface, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<code class="literal">64

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.routes
Desc: List of extra IPv6 static routes that will be assigned to the interface.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.routes._.address
Desc: IPv6 address of the network.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.routes._.options
Desc: Other route options. See the symbol <code class="literal">OPTIONS

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.routes._.prefixLength
Desc:
Subnet mask of the network, specified as the number of
bits in the prefix (<code class="literal">64

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.routes._.type
Desc: Type of the route.  See the <code class="literal">Route types

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.ipv6.routes._.via
Desc: IPv6 address of the next hop.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.macAddress
Desc: MAC address of the interface. Leave empty to use the default.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.mtu
Desc: MTU size for packets leaving the interface. Leave empty to use the default.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.name
Desc: Name of the interface.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.proxyARP
Desc:
Turn on proxy_arp for this device.
This is mainly useful for creating pseudo-bridges between a real
interface and a virtual network such as VPN or a virtual machine for
interfaces that don’t support real bridging (most wlan interfaces).
As ARP proxying acts slightly above the link-layer, below-ip traffic
isn’t bridged, so things like DHCP won’t work. The advantage above
using NAT lies in the fact that no IP addresses are shared, so all
hosts are reachable/routeable.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.tempAddress
Desc:
When IPv6 is enabled with SLAAC, this option controls the use of
temporary address (aka privacy extensions) on this
interface. This is used to reduce tracking.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.useDHCP
Desc:
Whether this interface should be configured with DHCP. Overrides the
default set by <code class="option">networking.useDHCP

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.virtual
Desc:
Whether this interface is virtual and should be created by tunctl.
This is mainly useful for creating bridges between a host and a virtual
network such as VPN or a virtual machine.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.virtualOwner
Desc: In case of a virtual device, the user who owns it.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.virtualType
Desc:
The type of interface to create.
The default is TUN for an interface name starting
with “tun”, otherwise TAP.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.wakeOnLan.enable
Desc: Whether to enable wol on this interface.

Name: networking.interfaces._name_.wakeOnLan.policy
Desc: The <a class="link" href="https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.link.html#WakeOnLan="  target="_top">Wake-on-LAN policy

Name: networking.iproute2.enable
Desc: Whether to enable copying IP route configuration files.

Name: networking.iproute2.rttablesExtraConfig
Desc: Verbatim lines to add to /etc/iproute2/rt_tables

Name: networking.jool.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable Jool, an Open Source implementation of IPv4/IPv6
translation on Linux.

Name: networking.jool.nat64
Desc:
Definitions of NAT64 instances of Jool.
See the
<a class="link" href="https://nicmx.github.io/Jool/en/config-atomic.html"  target="_top">documentation

Name: networking.jool.nat64._name_.framework
Desc:
The framework to use for attaching Jool’s translation to the exist
kernel packet processing rules. See the
<a class="link" href="https://nicmx.github.io/Jool/en/intro-jool.html#design"  target="_top">documentation

Name: networking.jool.nat64._name_.global.pool6
Desc:
The prefix used for embedding IPv4 into IPv6 addresses.
Defaults to the well-known NAT64 prefix, defined by
<a class="link" href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6052"  target="_top">RFC 6052

Name: networking.jool.siit
Desc:
Definitions of SIIT instances of Jool.
See the
<a class="link" href="https://nicmx.github.io/Jool/en/config-atomic.html"  target="_top">documentation

Name: networking.jool.siit._name_.framework
Desc:
The framework to use for attaching Jool’s translation to the exist
kernel packet processing rules. See the
<a class="link" href="https://nicmx.github.io/Jool/en/intro-jool.html#design"  target="_top">documentation

Name: networking.localCommands
Desc:
Shell commands to be executed at the end of the
<code class="literal">network-setup

Name: networking.macvlans
Desc:
This option allows you to define macvlan interfaces which should
be automatically created.

Name: networking.macvlans._name_.interface
Desc: The interface the macvlan will transmit packets through.

Name: networking.macvlans._name_.mode
Desc: The mode of the macvlan device.

Name: networking.nameservers
Desc: The list of nameservers.  It can be left empty if it is auto-detected through DHCP.

Name: networking.nat.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable Network Address Translation (NAT). A
properly configured firewall or a trusted L2 on all network
interfaces is required to prevent unauthorized access to
the internal network.

Name: networking.nat.enableIPv6
Desc: Whether to enable IPv6 NAT.

Name: networking.nat.dmzHost
Desc:
The local IP address to which all traffic that does not match any
forwarding rule is forwarded.

Name: networking.nat.externalIP
Desc:
The public IP address to which packets from the local
network are to be rewritten.  If this is left empty, the
IP address associated with the external interface will be
used.  Only connections made to this IP address will be
forwarded to the internal network when using forwardPorts.

Name: networking.nat.externalIPv6
Desc:
The public IPv6 address to which packets from the local
network are to be rewritten.  If this is left empty, the
IP address associated with the external interface will be
used.  Only connections made to this IP address will be
forwarded to the internal network when using forwardPorts.

Name: networking.nat.externalInterface
Desc: The name of the external network interface.

Name: networking.nat.extraCommands
Desc:
Additional shell commands executed as part of the nat
initialisation script.

Name: networking.nat.extraStopCommands
Desc:
Additional shell commands executed as part of the nat
teardown script.

Name: networking.nat.forwardPorts
Desc:
List of forwarded ports from the external interface to
internal destinations by using DNAT. Destination can be
IPv6 if IPv6 NAT is enabled.

Name: networking.nat.forwardPorts._.destination
Desc: Forward connection to destination ip:port (or [ipv6]:port); to specify a port range, use ip:start-end

Name: networking.nat.forwardPorts._.loopbackIPs

Desc:
The ruleset to be used with nftables.  Should be in a format that
can be loaded using “/bin/nft -f”.  The ruleset is updated atomically.
Note that if the tables should be cleaned first, either:

Name: networking.nftables.rulesetFile

Name: networking.proxy.allProxy

Name: networking.proxy.default

Desc: This option specifies the ftp_proxy environment variable.

Desc: This option specifies the http_proxy environment variable.

Desc: This option specifies the https_proxy environment variable.

This option specifies the no_proxy environment variable.
If a default proxy is used and noProxy is null,
then noProxy will be set to 127.0.0.1,localhost.

Desc: This option specifies the rsync_proxy environment variable.

Name: networking.resolvconf.enable
Desc: Whether DNS configuration is managed by resolvconf.

Name: networking.resolvconf.package
Desc: The package that provides the system-wide resolvconf command. Defaults to <code class="literal">openresolv

Name: networking.resolvconf.dnsExtensionMechanism
Desc: Enable the <code class="literal">edns0

Name: networking.resolvconf.dnsSingleRequest
Desc:
Recent versions of glibc will issue both ipv4 (A) and ipv6 (AAAA)
address queries at the same time, from the same port. Sometimes upstream
routers will systemically drop the ipv4 queries. The symptom of this problem is
that ‘getent hosts example.com’ only returns ipv6 (or perhaps only ipv4) addresses. The
workaround for this is to specify the option ‘single-request’ in
/etc/resolv.conf. This option enables that.

Name: networking.resolvconf.extraConfig
Desc: Extra configuration to append to <code class="filename">resolvconf.conf

Name: networking.resolvconf.extraOptions
Desc: Set the options in <code class="filename">/etc/resolv.conf

Name: networking.resolvconf.useLocalResolver
Desc: Use local DNS server for resolving.

Name: networking.rxe.enable
Desc: Whether to enable RDMA over converged ethernet.

Name: networking.rxe.interfaces
Desc:
Enable RDMA on the listed interfaces. The corresponding virtual
RDMA interfaces will be named rxe_<interface>.
UDP port 4791 must be open on the respective ethernet interfaces.

Name: networking.search
Desc: The list of search paths used when resolving domain names.

Desc: This option allows you to define 6-to-4 interfaces which should be automatically created.

Type: null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Selects encapsulation type. See
<span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">ip-link

The address of the local endpoint which the remote
side should send packets to.

Name: networking.sits._name_.remote
Desc: The address of the remote endpoint to forward traffic over.

Name: networking.sits._name_.ttl

Name: networking.supplicant._name_.extraConf
Desc: Configuration options for <code class="literal">wpa_supplicant.conf

Name: networking.supplicant._name_.userControlled.enable
Desc:
Allow normal users to control wpa_supplicant through wpa_gui or wpa_cli.
This is useful for laptop users that switch networks a lot and don’t want
to depend on a large package such as NetworkManager just to pick nearby
access points.

Name: networking.supplicant._name_.userControlled.group
Desc: Members of this group can control wpa_supplicant.

Name: networking.supplicant._name_.userControlled.socketDir
Desc: Directory of sockets for controlling wpa_supplicant.

Name: networking.tcpcrypt.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable opportunistic TCP encryption. If the other end
speaks Tcpcrypt, then your traffic will be encrypted; otherwise
it will be sent in clear text. Thus, Tcpcrypt alone provides no
guarantees – it is best effort. If, however, a Tcpcrypt
connection is successful and any attackers that exist are
passive, then Tcpcrypt guarantees privacy.

Name: networking.tempAddresses
Desc:
Whether to enable IPv6 Privacy Extensions for interfaces not
configured explicitly in
<a class='xref' href='/manual/nixos/unstable/options#opt-networking.interfaces._name_.tempAddress'><code class="option">networking.interfaces.<name>.tempAddress

Name: networking.timeServers
Desc: The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.

Name: networking.ucarp.enable
Desc: Whether to enable ucarp, userspace implementation of CARP.

Desc:
The ucarp package to use. Please note that the default package, pkgs.ucarp, has not received any
upstream updates for a long time and can be considered as unmaintained.

Desc: Virtual shared IP address.

Desc: Advertisement frequency in seconds.

Desc: Use broadcast instead of multicast advertisements.

Desc: File containing shared password between CARP hosts.

Name: networking.ucarp.preempt
Desc:
Enable preemptive failover.
Thus, this host becomes the CARP master as soon as possible.

Name: networking.ucarp.shutdown
Desc: Call downscript at exit.

Name: networking.ucarp.srcIp
Desc: Source (real) IP address of this host.

Name: networking.ucarp.upscript
Desc:
Command to run after become master, the interface name, virtual address
and optional extra parameters are passed as arguments.

Name: networking.ucarp.vhId
Desc: Virtual IP identifier shared between CARP hosts.

Desc:
Whether to use DHCP to obtain an IP address and other
configuration for all network interfaces that do not have any manually
configured IPv4 addresses.

Desc:
In containers, whether to use the
<code class="filename">resolv.conf

Desc:
Whether we should use networkd as the network configuration backend or

Desc: Whether to assign <a class="link" href="https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/systemd/PredictableNetworkInterfaceNames/"  target="_top">predictable names to network interfaces

Desc:
This option allows you to define vlan devices that tag packets
on top of a physical interface. The value of this option is an
attribute set. Each attribute specifies a vlan, with the name
specifying the name of the vlan interface.

Name: networking.vlans._name_.id
Desc: The vlan identifier

Name: networking.vlans._name_.interface
Desc: The interface the vlan will transmit packets through.
