Desc:
This option allows you to define Open vSwitches that connect
physical networks together. The value of this option is an
attribute set. Each attribute specifies a vswitch, with the
attribute name specifying the name of the vswitch’s network
interface.

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.controllers
Desc: Specify the controller targets. For the allowed options see <code class="literal">man 8 ovs-vsctl

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.extraOvsctlCmds
Desc: Commands to manipulate the Open vSwitch database. Every line executed with <code class="literal">ovs-vsctl

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.interfaces
Desc: The physical network interfaces connected by the vSwitch.

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.interfaces._name_.name
Desc: Name of the interface

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.interfaces._name_.type
Desc: Openvswitch type to assign to interface

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.interfaces._name_.vlan
Desc: Vlan tag to apply to interface

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.openFlowRules
Desc: OpenFlow rules to insert into the Open vSwitch. All <code class="literal">openFlowRules

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.openFlowVersion
Desc: Version of OpenFlow protocol to use when communicating with the switch internally (e.g. with <code class="literal">openFlowRules

Name: networking.vswitches._name_.supportedOpenFlowVersions
Desc: Supported versions to enable on this switch.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces
Desc: Wireguard interfaces.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.address
Desc: The IP addresses of the interface.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.autostart
Desc: Whether to bring up this interface automatically during boot.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.configFile
Desc:
wg-quick .conf file, describing the interface.
Using this option can be a useful means of configuring WireGuard if
one has an existing .conf file.
This overrides any other configuration interface configuration options.
See wg-quick manpage for more details.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.dns
Desc: The IP addresses of DNS servers to configure.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.generatePrivateKeyFile
Desc:
Automatically generate a private key with
<span class="command"><strong>wg genkey

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.listenPort
Desc:
16-bit port for listening. Optional; if not specified,
automatically generated based on interface name.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.mtu
Desc:
If not specified, the MTU is automatically determined
from the endpoint addresses or the system default route, which is usually
a sane choice. However, to manually specify an MTU to override this
automatic discovery, this value may be specified explicitly.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.peers
Desc: Peers linked to the interface.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.peers._.allowedIPs
Desc:
List of IP (v4 or v6) addresses with CIDR masks from
which this peer is allowed to send incoming traffic and to which
outgoing traffic for this peer is directed. The catch-all 0.0.0.0/0 may
be specified for matching all IPv4 addresses, and ::/0 may be specified
for matching all IPv6 addresses.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.peers._.endpoint
Desc:
Endpoint IP or hostname of the peer, followed by a colon,
and then a port number of the peer.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.peers._.persistentKeepalive
Desc:
This is optional and is by default off, because most
users will not need it. It represents, in seconds, between 1 and 65535
inclusive, how often to send an authenticated empty packet to the peer,
for the purpose of keeping a stateful firewall or NAT mapping valid
persistently. For example, if the interface very rarely sends traffic,
but it might at anytime receive traffic from a peer, and it is behind
NAT, the interface might benefit from having a persistent keepalive
interval of 25 seconds; however, most users will not need this.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.peers._.presharedKey
Desc: Base64 preshared key generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genpsk

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.peers._.presharedKeyFile
Desc: File pointing to preshared key as generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genpsk

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.peers._.publicKey
Desc: The base64 public key to the peer.

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.postDown
Desc: Command called after the interface is taken down.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.postUp
Desc: Commands called after the interface setup.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.preDown
Desc: Command called before the interface is taken down.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.preUp
Desc: Commands called at the start of the interface setup.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.privateKey
Desc: Base64 private key generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genkey

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.privateKeyFile
Desc: Private key file as generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genkey

Name: networking.wg-quick.interfaces._name_.table
Desc:
The kernel routing table to add this interface’s
associated routes to. Setting this is useful for e.g. policy routing
(“ip rule”) or virtual routing and forwarding (“ip vrf”). Both
numeric table IDs and table names (/etc/rt_tables) can be used.
Defaults to “main”.

Name: networking.wireguard.enable
Desc: Whether to enable WireGuard.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces
Desc: WireGuard interfaces.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.allowedIPsAsRoutes
Desc: Determines whether to add allowed IPs as routes or not.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.dynamicEndpointRefreshSeconds
Desc:
Periodically refresh the endpoint hostname or address for all peers.
Allows WireGuard to notice DNS and IPv4/IPv6 connectivity changes.
This option can be set or overridden for individual peers.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.fwMark
Desc:
Mark all wireguard packets originating from
this interface with the given firewall mark. The firewall mark can be
used in firewalls or policy routing to filter the wireguard packets.
This can be useful for setup where all traffic goes through the
wireguard tunnel, because the wireguard packets need to be routed
differently.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.generatePrivateKeyFile
Desc:
Automatically generate a private key with
<span class="command"><strong>wg genkey

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.interfaceNamespace
Desc:
The pre-existing network namespace the WireGuard
interface is moved to. The special value <code class="literal">init

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.ips
Desc: The IP addresses of the interface.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.listenPort
Desc:
16-bit port for listening. Optional; if not specified,
automatically generated based on interface name.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.metric
Desc: Set the metric of routes related to this Wireguard interface.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.mtu
Desc:
Set the maximum transmission unit in bytes for the wireguard
interface. Beware that the wireguard packets have a header that may
add up to 80 bytes to the mtu. By default, the MTU is (1500 - 80) =
1420. However, if the MTU of the upstream network is lower, the MTU
of the wireguard network has to be adjusted as well.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers
Desc: Peers linked to the interface.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.allowedIPs
Desc:
List of IP (v4 or v6) addresses with CIDR masks from
which this peer is allowed to send incoming traffic and to which
outgoing traffic for this peer is directed. The catch-all 0.0.0.0/0 may
be specified for matching all IPv4 addresses, and ::/0 may be specified
for matching all IPv6 addresses.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.dynamicEndpointRefreshRestartSeconds
Desc:
When the dynamic endpoint refresh that is configured via
dynamicEndpointRefreshSeconds exits (likely due to a failure),
restart that service after this many seconds.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.dynamicEndpointRefreshSeconds
Desc: Periodically re-execute the <code class="literal">wg

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.endpoint
Desc:
Endpoint IP or hostname of the peer, followed by a colon,
and then a port number of the peer.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.name
Desc: Name used to derive peer unit name.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.persistentKeepalive
Desc:
This is optional and is by default off, because most
users will not need it. It represents, in seconds, between 1 and 65535
inclusive, how often to send an authenticated empty packet to the peer,
for the purpose of keeping a stateful firewall or NAT mapping valid
persistently. For example, if the interface very rarely sends traffic,
but it might at anytime receive traffic from a peer, and it is behind
NAT, the interface might benefit from having a persistent keepalive
interval of 25 seconds; however, most users will not need this.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.presharedKey
Desc: Base64 preshared key generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genpsk

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.presharedKeyFile
Desc: File pointing to preshared key as generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genpsk

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.peers._.publicKey
Desc: The base64 public key of the peer.

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.postSetup
Desc: Commands called at the end of the interface setup.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.postShutdown
Desc: Commands called after shutting down the interface.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.preSetup
Desc: Commands called at the start of the interface setup.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.preShutdown
Desc: Commands called before shutting down the interface.
Type: strings concatenated with “\n” or (list of string) convertible to it

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.privateKey
Desc: Base64 private key generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genkey

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.privateKeyFile
Desc: Private key file as generated by <span class="command"><strong>wg genkey

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.socketNamespace
Desc:
The pre-existing network namespace in which the
WireGuard interface is created, and which retains the socket even if the
interface is moved via <code class="option">interfaceNamespace

Name: networking.wireguard.interfaces._name_.table
Desc:
The kernel routing table to add this interface’s
associated routes to. Setting this is useful for e.g. policy routing
(“ip rule”) or virtual routing and forwarding (“ip vrf”). Both
numeric table IDs and table names (/etc/rt_tables) can be used.
Defaults to “main”.

Name: networking.wireguard.useNetworkd
Desc:
Whether to use networkd as the network configuration backend for
Wireguard instead of the legacy script-based system.

Name: networking.wireless.enable
Desc: Whether to enable wpa_supplicant.

Name: networking.wireless.allowAuxiliaryImperativeNetworks
Desc:
Whether to allow configuring networks “imperatively” (e.g. via
<code class="literal">wpa_supplicant_gui

Name: networking.wireless.athUserRegulatoryDomain
Desc:
If enabled, sets the ATH_USER_REGD kernel config switch to true to
disable the enforcement of EEPROM regulatory restrictions for ath
drivers. Requires at least Linux 5.8.

Name: networking.wireless.dbusControlled
Desc:
Whether to enable the DBus control interface.
This is only needed when using NetworkManager or connman.

Name: networking.wireless.driver
Desc: Force a specific wpa_supplicant driver.

Name: networking.wireless.extraConfig
Desc:
Extra lines appended to the configuration file.
See
<span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">wpa_supplicant.conf

Name: networking.wireless.fallbackToWPA2
Desc:
Whether to fall back to WPA2 authentication protocols if WPA3 failed.
This allows old wireless cards (that lack recent features required by
WPA3) to connect to mixed WPA2/WPA3 access points.

Name: networking.wireless.interfaces
Desc: The interfaces <span class="command"><strong>wpa_supplicant

Name: networking.wireless.iwd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable iwd.

Name: networking.wireless.iwd.package
Desc: The iwd package to use.

Name: networking.wireless.iwd.settings
Desc:
Options passed to iwd.
See <span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">iwd.config
Type: attribute set of section of an INI file (attrs of INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

Name: networking.wireless.networks
Desc:
The network definitions to automatically connect to when
<span class="command"><strong>wpa_supplicant

Name: networking.wireless.networks._name_.auth
Desc:
Use this option to configure advanced authentication methods
like EAP. See <span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">wpa_supplicant.conf

Name: networking.wireless.networks._name_.authProtocols
Desc:
The list of authentication protocols accepted by this network.
This corresponds to the <code class="literal">key_mgmt

Name: networking.wireless.networks._name_.extraConfig
Desc:
Extra configuration lines appended to the network block.
See <span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">wpa_supplicant.conf

Name: networking.wireless.networks._name_.hidden
Desc: Set this to <code class="literal">true

Name: networking.wireless.networks._name_.priority
Desc:
By default, all networks will get same priority group (0). If
some of the networks are more desirable, this field can be used
to change the order in which wpa_supplicant goes through the
networks when selecting a BSS. The priority groups will be
iterated in decreasing priority (i.e., the larger the priority
value, the sooner the network is matched against the scan
results). Within each priority group, networks will be selected
based on security policy, signal strength, etc.

Name: networking.wireless.networks._name_.psk
Desc:
The network’s pre-shared key in plaintext defaulting
to being a network without any authentication.
Type: null or string matching the pattern [[:print:]]{8,63}

Name: networking.wireless.networks._name_.pskRaw
Desc:
Either the raw pre-shared key in hexadecimal format
or the name of the secret (as defined inside
<a class='xref' href='/manual/nixos/unstable/options#opt-networking.wireless.secretsFile'><code class="option">networking.wireless.secretsFile
Type: null or string matching the pattern ([[:xdigit:]]{64})|(ext:[^=]+)

Name: networking.wireless.scanOnLowSignal
Desc:
Whether to periodically scan for (better) networks when the signal of
the current one is low. This will make roaming between access points
faster, but will consume more power.

Name: networking.wireless.secretsFile
Desc: File consisting of lines of the form <code class="literal">varname=value

Name: networking.wireless.userControlled.enable
Desc:
Allow normal users to control wpa_supplicant through wpa_gui or wpa_cli.
This is useful for laptop users that switch networks a lot and don’t want
to depend on a large package such as NetworkManager just to pick nearby
access points.

Name: networking.wireless.userControlled.group
Desc: Members of this group can control wpa_supplicant.

Name: networking.wlanInterfaces
Desc: Creating multiple WLAN interfaces on top of one physical WLAN device (NIC).

Name: networking.wlanInterfaces._name_.device
Desc: The name of the underlying hardware WLAN device as assigned by <code class="literal">udev

Name: networking.wlanInterfaces._name_.flags
Desc: Flags for interface of type <code class="literal">monitor

Name: networking.wlanInterfaces._name_.fourAddr
Desc: Whether to enable <code class="literal">4-address mode

Name: networking.wlanInterfaces._name_.mac
Desc: MAC address to use for the device. If <code class="literal">null

Name: networking.wlanInterfaces._name_.meshID
Desc: MeshID of interface with type <code class="literal">mesh

Name: networking.wlanInterfaces._name_.type
Desc:
The type of the WLAN interface.
The type has to be supported by the underlying hardware of the device.

Name: nix.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable Nix.
Disabling Nix makes the system hard to modify and the Nix programs and configuration will not be made available by NixOS itself.

Name: nix.package
Desc: This option specifies the Nix package instance to use throughout the system.

Name: nix.buildMachines
Desc:
This option lists the machines to be used if distributed builds are
enabled (see <code class="option">nix.distributedBuilds

Name: nix.buildMachines._.hostName
Desc: The hostname of the build machine.

Name: nix.buildMachines._.mandatoryFeatures
Desc:
A list of features mandatory for this builder. The builder will
be ignored for derivations that don’t require all features in
this list. All mandatory features are automatically included in
<code class="varname">supportedFeatures

Name: nix.buildMachines._.maxJobs
Desc:
The number of concurrent jobs the build machine supports. The
build machine will enforce its own limits, but this allows hydra
to schedule better since there is no work-stealing between build
machines.

Name: nix.buildMachines._.protocol
Desc:
The protocol used for communicating with the build machine.
Use <code class="literal">ssh-ng

Name: nix.buildMachines._.publicHostKey
Desc:
The (base64-encoded) public host key of this builder. The field
is calculated via <span class="command"><strong>base64 -w0 /etc/ssh/ssh_host_type_key.pub

Name: nix.buildMachines._.speedFactor
Desc:
The relative speed of this builder. This is an arbitrary integer
that indicates the speed of this builder, relative to other
builders. Higher is faster.

Name: nix.buildMachines._.sshKey
Desc:
The path to the SSH private key with which to authenticate on
the build machine. The private key must not have a passphrase.
If null, the building user (root on NixOS machines) must have an
appropriate ssh configuration to log in non-interactively.

Name: nix.buildMachines._.sshUser
Desc:
The username to log in as on the remote host. This user must be
able to log in and run nix commands non-interactively. It must
also be privileged to build derivations, so must be included in
<code class="option">nix.settings.trusted-users

Name: nix.buildMachines._.supportedFeatures
Desc:
A list of features supported by this builder. The builder will
be ignored for derivations that require features not in this
list.

Name: nix.buildMachines._.system
Desc:
The system type the build machine can execute derivations on.
Either this attribute or <code class="varname">systems

Name: nix.buildMachines._.systems
Desc:
The system types the build machine can execute derivations on.
Either this attribute or <code class="varname">system

Name: nix.channel.enable
Desc: Whether the <code class="literal">nix-channel

Name: nix.checkAllErrors
Desc: If enabled, checks the nix.conf parsing for any kind of error. When disabled, checks only for unknown settings.

Name: nix.checkConfig
Desc: If enabled, checks that Nix can parse the generated nix.conf.

Name: nix.daemonCPUSchedPolicy
Desc:
Nix daemon process CPU scheduling policy. This policy propagates to
build processes. <code class="literal">other

Name: nix.daemonIOSchedClass
Desc:
Nix daemon process I/O scheduling class. This class propagates to
build processes. <code class="literal">best-effort

Name: nix.daemonIOSchedPriority
Desc:
Nix daemon process I/O scheduling priority. This priority propagates
to build processes. The supported priorities depend on the
scheduling policy: With idle, priorities are not used in scheduling
decisions. best-effort supports values in the range 0 (high) to 7
(low).

Name: nix.distributedBuilds
Desc:
Whether to distribute builds to the machines listed in
<code class="option">nix.buildMachines

Name: nix.extraOptions
Desc: Additional text appended to <code class="filename">nix.conf

Name: nix.gc.automatic
Desc: Automatically run the garbage collector at a specific time.

Name: nix.gc.dates
Desc:
How often or when garbage collection is performed. For most desktop and server systems
a sufficient garbage collection is once a week.

Name: nix.gc.options
Desc: Options given to <a class="link" href="https://nixos.org/manual/nix/stable/command-ref/nix-collect-garbage"  target="_top"><code class="literal">nix-collect-garbage

Name: nix.gc.persistent
Desc:
Takes a boolean argument. If true, the time when the service
unit was last triggered is stored on disk. When the timer is
activated, the service unit is triggered immediately if it
would have been triggered at least once during the time when
the timer was inactive. Such triggering is nonetheless
subject to the delay imposed by RandomizedDelaySec=. This is
useful to catch up on missed runs of the service when the
system was powered down.

Name: nix.gc.randomizedDelaySec
Desc:
Add a randomized delay before each garbage collection.
The delay will be chosen between zero and this value.
This value must be a time span in the format specified by
<a class="link" href="https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.time.html" target="_top"><span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">systemd.time

Name: nix.nixPath
nix.nrBuildUsers
Desc: Number of <code class="literal">nixbld

Name: nix.optimise.automatic
Desc: Automatically run the nix store optimiser at a specific time.

Name: nix.optimise.dates
Desc:
Specification (in the format described by
<a class="link" href="https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.time.html" target="_top"><span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">systemd.time

Name: nix.registry
Desc: A system-wide flake registry.

Name: nix.registry._name_.exact
Desc: Whether the <code class="option">from

Name: nix.registry._name_.flake
Desc: The flake input <code class="option">from

Name: nix.registry._name_.from
Desc: The flake reference to be rewritten.
Type: attribute set of (string or signed integer or boolean or path or package)

Name: nix.registry._name_.to
Desc: The flake reference <code class="option">from
Type: attribute set of (string or signed integer or boolean or path or package)

Name: nix.settings
Desc:
Configuration for Nix, see
<a class='link' href='https://nixos.org/manual/nix/stable/command-ref/conf-file' target='_top'>https://nixos.org/manual/nix/stable/command-ref/conf-file.html
Type: attribute set of (Nix config atom (null, bool, int, float, str, path or package) or list of (Nix config atom (null, bool, int, float, str, path or package)))

Name: nix.settings.allowed-users
Desc:
A list of names of users (separated by whitespace) that are
allowed to connect to the Nix daemon. As with
<code class="option">nix.settings.trusted-users

Name: nix.settings.auto-optimise-store
Desc:
If set to true, Nix automatically detects files in the store that have
identical contents, and replaces them with hard links to a single copy.
This saves disk space. If set to false (the default), you can still run
nix-store --optimise to get rid of duplicate files.

Name: nix.settings.cores
Desc:
This option defines the maximum number of concurrent tasks during
one build. It affects, e.g., -j option for make.
The special value 0 means that the builder should use all
available CPU cores in the system. Some builds may become
non-deterministic with this option; use with care! Packages will
only be affected if enableParallelBuilding is set for them.

Name: nix.settings.extra-sandbox-paths
Desc:
Directories from the host filesystem to be included
in the sandbox.

Name: nix.settings.max-jobs
Desc:
This option defines the maximum number of jobs that Nix will try to
build in parallel. The default is auto, which means it will use all
available logical cores. It is recommend to set it to the total
number of logical cores in your system (e.g., 16 for two CPUs with 4
cores each and hyper-threading).

Name: nix.settings.require-sigs
Desc:
If enabled (the default), Nix will only download binaries from binary caches if
they are cryptographically signed with any of the keys listed in
<code class="option">nix.settings.trusted-public-keys

Name: nix.settings.sandbox
Desc:
If set, Nix will perform builds in a sandboxed environment that it
will set up automatically for each build. This prevents impurities
in builds by disallowing access to dependencies outside of the Nix
store by using network and mount namespaces in a chroot environment.

Name: nix.settings.substituters
Desc:
List of binary cache URLs used to obtain pre-built binaries
of Nix packages.

Name: nix.settings.system-features
Desc:
The set of features supported by the machine. Derivations
can express dependencies on system features through the
<code class="literal">requiredSystemFeatures

Name: nix.settings.trusted-public-keys
Desc:
List of public keys used to sign binary caches. If
<code class="option">nix.settings.trusted-public-keys

Name: nix.settings.trusted-substituters
Desc:
List of binary cache URLs that non-root users can use (in
addition to those specified using
<code class="option">nix.settings.substituters

Name: nix.settings.trusted-users
Desc:
A list of names of users that have additional rights when
connecting to the Nix daemon, such as the ability to specify
additional binary caches, or to import unsigned NARs. You
can also specify groups by prefixing them with
<code class="literal">@

Name: nix.sshServe.enable
Desc: Whether to enable serving the Nix store as a remote store via SSH.

Name: nix.sshServe.keys
Desc: A list of SSH public keys allowed to access the binary cache via SSH.

Name: nix.sshServe.protocol
Desc: The specific Nix-over-SSH protocol to use.

Name: nix.sshServe.write
Desc: Whether to enable writing to the Nix store as a remote store via SSH. Note: the sshServe user is named nix-ssh and is not a trusted-user. nix-ssh should be added to the <code class="option">nix.settings.trusted-users

Name: nixops.enableDeprecatedAutoLuks
Desc: Whether to enable the deprecated NixOps AutoLuks module.

Name: nixpkgs.buildPlatform
Desc:
Specifies the platform on which NixOS should be built.
By default, NixOS is built on the system where it runs, but you can
change where it’s built. Setting this option will cause NixOS to be
cross-compiled.

Name: nixpkgs.config
Desc:
Global configuration for Nixpkgs.
The complete list of <a class="link" href="https://nixos.org/manual/nixpkgs/unstable/#sec-config-options-reference"  target="_top">Nixpkgs configuration options

Name: nixpkgs.crossSystem
Desc: Systems with a recently generated <code class="literal">hardware-configuration.nix

Name: nixpkgs.flake.setFlakeRegistry
Desc: Whether to pin nixpkgs in the system-wide flake registry (<code class="literal">/etc/nix/registry.json

Name: nixpkgs.flake.setNixPath
Desc: Whether to set <code class="envar">NIX_PATH

Name: nixpkgs.flake.source
Desc:
The path to the nixpkgs sources used to build the system. This is automatically set up to be
the store path of the nixpkgs flake used to build the system if using
<code class="literal">nixpkgs.lib.nixosSystem

Name: nixpkgs.hostPlatform
Desc: Specifies the platform where the NixOS configuration will run.

Name: nixpkgs.localSystem
Desc: Systems with a recently generated <code class="literal">hardware-configuration.nix

Name: nixpkgs.overlays
Desc:
List of overlays to apply to Nixpkgs.
This option allows modifying the Nixpkgs package set accessed through the <code class="literal">pkgs

Name: nixpkgs.pkgs
Desc:
If set, the pkgs argument to all NixOS modules is the value of
this option, extended with <code class="literal">nixpkgs.overlays
Type: An evaluation of Nixpkgs; the top level attribute set of packages

Name: nixpkgs.system
Desc:
This option does not need to be specified for NixOS configurations
with a recently generated <code class="literal">hardware-configuration.nix

Name: openstack.zfs.datasets
Desc: Datasets to create under the <code class="literal">tank

Name: openstack.zfs.datasets._name_.mount
Desc: Where to mount this dataset.

Name: openstack.zfs.datasets._name_.properties
Desc: Properties to set on this dataset.

Name: power.ups.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable support for Power Devices, such as Uninterruptible Power
Supplies, Power Distribution Units and Solar Controllers
.

Name: power.ups.maxStartDelay
Desc:
This can be set as a global variable above your first UPS
definition and it can also be set in a UPS section.  This value
controls how long upsdrvctl will wait for the driver to finish
starting.  This keeps your system from getting stuck due to a
broken driver or UPS.

Name: power.ups.mode
Desc:
The MODE determines which part of the NUT is to be started, and
which configuration files must be modified.

Name: power.ups.openFirewall
Desc: Open ports in the firewall for <code class="literal">upsd

Name: power.ups.schedulerRules
Desc: File which contains the rules to handle UPS events.

Name: power.ups.ups
Desc:
This is where you configure all the UPSes that this system will be
monitoring directly.  These are usually attached to serial ports,
but USB devices are also supported.

Name: power.ups.ups._name_.description
Desc: Description of the UPS.

Name: power.ups.ups._name_.directives
Desc: List of configuration directives for this UPS.

Name: power.ups.ups._name_.driver
Desc:
Specify the program to run to talk to this UPS.  apcsmart,
bestups, and sec are some examples.

Name: power.ups.ups._name_.maxStartDelay
Desc:
This can be set as a global variable above your first UPS
definition and it can also be set in a UPS section.  This value
controls how long upsdrvctl will wait for the driver to finish
starting.  This keeps your system from getting stuck due to a
broken driver or UPS.

Name: power.ups.ups._name_.port
Desc:
The serial port to which your UPS is connected.  /dev/ttyS0 is
usually the first port on Linux boxes, for example.

Name: power.ups.ups._name_.shutdownOrder
Desc:
When you have multiple UPSes on your system, you usually need to
turn them off in a certain order.  upsdrvctl shuts down all the
0s, then the 1s, 2s, and so on.  To exclude a UPS from the
shutdown sequence, set this to -1.

Name: power.ups.ups._name_.summary
Desc: Lines which would be added inside ups.conf for handling this UPS.

Name: power.ups.upsd
Desc: Options for the <code class="literal">upsd.conf

Name: power.ups.upsd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable <code class="literal">upsd

Name: power.ups.upsd.extraConfig
Desc: Additional lines to add to <code class="literal">upsd.conf

Name: power.ups.upsd.listen
Desc: Address of the interface for <code class="literal">upsd

Name: power.ups.upsd.listen._.address
Desc: Address of the interface for <code class="literal">upsd

Name: power.ups.upsd.listen._.port
Desc: TCP port for <code class="literal">upsd
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: power.ups.upsmon
Desc: Options for the <code class="literal">upsmon.conf

Name: power.ups.upsmon.enable
Desc: Whether to enable <code class="literal">upsmon

Name: power.ups.upsmon.monitor
Desc: Set of UPS to monitor. See <code class="literal">man upsmon.conf

Name: power.ups.upsmon.monitor._name_.passwordFile
Desc:
The full path to a file containing the password from
<code class="literal">upsd.users

Name: power.ups.upsmon.monitor._name_.powerValue
Desc:
Number of power supplies that the UPS feeds on this system.
See <code class="literal">upsmon.conf

Name: power.ups.upsmon.monitor._name_.system
Desc: Identifier of the UPS to monitor, in this form: <code class="literal"><upsname>[@<hostname>[:<port>]]

Name: power.ups.upsmon.monitor._name_.type
Desc: The relationship with <code class="literal">upsd

Name: power.ups.upsmon.monitor._name_.user
Desc: Username from <code class="literal">upsd.users

Name: power.ups.upsmon.settings
Desc: Additional settings to add to <code class="literal">upsmon.conf
Type: attribute set of (atom (null, bool, int, float or string) or list of non-empty (list of (atom (null, bool, int, float or string))))

Name: power.ups.users
Desc: Users that can access upsd. See <code class="literal">man upsd.users

Name: power.ups.users._name_.actions
Desc:
Allow the user to do certain things with upsd.
See <code class="literal">man upsd.users

Name: power.ups.users._name_.instcmds
Desc:
Let the user initiate specific instant commands. Use “ALL” to grant all commands automatically. For the full list of what your UPS supports, use “upscmd -l”.
See <code class="literal">man upsd.users

Name: power.ups.users._name_.passwordFile
Desc:
The full path to a file that contains the user’s (clear text)
password. The password file is read on service start.

Name: power.ups.users._name_.upsmon
Desc:
Add the necessary actions for a upsmon process to work.
See <code class="literal">man upsd.users

Name: powerManagement.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable power management.  This includes support
for suspend-to-RAM and powersave features on laptops.

Name: powerManagement.cpuFreqGovernor
Desc:
Configure the governor used to regulate the frequency of the
available CPUs. By default, the kernel configures the
performance governor, although this may be overwritten in your
hardware-configuration.nix file.

Name: powerManagement.cpufreq.max
Desc: The maximum frequency the CPU will use.  Defaults to the maximum possible.

Name: powerManagement.cpufreq.min
Desc: The minimum frequency the CPU will use.

Name: powerManagement.powerDownCommands
Desc:
Commands executed when the machine powers down.  That is,
they’re executed both when the system shuts down and when
it goes to suspend or hibernation.

Name: powerManagement.powerUpCommands
Desc:
Commands executed when the machine powers up.  That is,
they’re executed both when the system first boots and when
it resumes from suspend or hibernation.

Name: powerManagement.powertop.enable
Desc: Whether to enable powertop auto tuning on startup.

Name: powerManagement.resumeCommands
Desc: Commands executed after the system resumes from suspend-to-RAM.

Name: powerManagement.scsiLinkPolicy
Desc:
SCSI link power management policy. The kernel default is
“max_performance”.

Name: programs._1password.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the 1Password CLI tool.

Name: programs._1password.package
Desc: The 1Password CLI package to use.

Name: programs._1password-gui.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the 1Password GUI application.

Name: programs._1password-gui.package
Desc: The 1Password GUI package to use.

Name: programs._1password-gui.polkitPolicyOwners
Desc: A list of users who should be able to integrate 1Password with polkit-based authentication mechanisms.

Name: programs.adb.enable
programs.alvr.enable
Desc: Whether to enable ALVR, the VR desktop streamer.

Name: programs.alvr.package
Desc: The alvr package to use.

Name: programs.alvr.openFirewall
Desc: Whether to open the default ports in the firewall for the ALVR server.

Name: programs.appgate-sdp.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the AppGate SDP VPN client.

Name: programs.appimage.enable
Desc: Whether to enable appimage-run wrapper script for executing appimages on NixOS.

Name: programs.appimage.package
Desc: The appimage-run package to use.

Name: programs.appimage.binfmt
Desc: Whether to enable binfmt registration to run appimages via appimage-run seamlessly.

Name: programs.arp-scan.enable
Desc: Whether to configure a setcap wrapper for arp-scan.

Name: programs.atop.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Atop, a tool for monitoring system resources.

Name: programs.atop.package
Desc: The atop package to use.

Name: programs.atop.atopRotateTimer.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable the atop-rotate timer, which restarts the atop service
daily to make sure the data files are rotate.

Name: programs.atop.atopService.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable the atop service responsible for storing statistics for
long-term analysis.

Name: programs.atop.atopacctService.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable the atopacct service which manages process accounting.
This allows Atop to gather data about processes that disappeared in between
two refresh intervals.

Name: programs.atop.atopgpu.enable
Desc:
Whether to install and enable the atopgpud daemon to get information about
NVIDIA gpus.

Name: programs.atop.netatop.enable
Desc:
Whether to install and enable the netatop kernel module.
Note: this sets the kernel taint flag “O” for loading out-of-tree modules.

Name: programs.atop.netatop.package
Desc: Which package to use for netatop.

Name: programs.atop.settings
Desc: Parameters to be written to <code class="filename">/etc/atoprc

Name: programs.atop.setuidWrapper.enable
Desc:
Whether to install a setuid wrapper for Atop. This is required to use some of
the features as non-root user (e.g.: ipc information, netatop, atopgpu).
Atop tries to drop the root privileges shortly after starting.

Name: programs.ausweisapp.enable
Desc: Whether to enable AusweisApp.

Name: programs.ausweisapp.openFirewall
Desc: Whether to open the required firewall ports for the Smartphone as Card Reader (SaC) functionality of AusweisApp.

Name: programs.autojump.enable
Desc: Whether to enable autojump.

Name: programs.bandwhich.enable
Desc:
Whether to add bandwhich to the global environment and configure a
setcap wrapper for it.

Name: programs.bash.enableLsColors
Desc: Whether to enable extra colors in directory listings.

Name: programs.bash.blesh.enable
Desc: Whether to enable blesh, a full-featured line editor written in pure Bash.

Name: programs.bash.completion.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Bash completion for all interactive bash shells.

Name: programs.bash.completion.package
Desc: The bash-completion package to use.

Name: programs.bash.interactiveShellInit
Desc: Shell script code called during interactive bash shell initialisation.

Name: programs.bash.loginShellInit
Desc: Shell script code called during login bash shell initialisation.

Name: programs.bash.promptInit
Desc: Shell script code used to initialise the bash prompt.

Name: programs.bash.shellAliases
Desc: Set of aliases for bash shell, which overrides <code class="option">environment.shellAliases
Type: attribute set of (null or string or path)

Name: programs.ssh.forwardX11
Desc:
Whether to request X11 forwarding on outgoing connections by default.
If set to null, the option is not set at all.
This is useful for running graphical programs on the remote machine and have them display to your local X11 server.
Historically, this value has depended on the value used by the local sshd daemon, but there really isn’t a relation between the two.
Note: there are some security risks to forwarding an X11 connection.
NixOS’s X server is built with the SECURITY extension, which prevents some obvious attacks.
To enable or disable forwarding on a per-connection basis, see the -X and -x options to ssh.
The -Y option to ssh enables trusted forwarding, which bypasses the SECURITY extension.

Name: programs.ssh.hostKeyAlgorithms

Name: programs.ssh.kexAlgorithms

Name: programs.ssh.knownHosts

for the entry. This behaviour can be disabled by setting
<code class="literal">hostNames

Name: programs.ssh.knownHosts._name_.certAuthority

individual host’s key.

Name: programs.ssh.knownHosts._name_.extraHostNames

accessing the host’s ssh service. This list is ignored if
<code class="literal">hostNames

Name: programs.ssh.knownHosts._name_.hostNames

the host’s ssh service. This list includes the name of the
containing <code class="literal">knownHosts

Name: programs.ssh.knownHosts._name_.publicKey

The public key data for the host. You can fetch a public key
from a running SSH server with the <span class="command"><strong>ssh-keyscan

Name: programs.ssh.knownHosts._name_.publicKeyFile
Desc:
The path to the public key file for the host. The public
key file is read at build time and saved in the Nix store.
You can fetch a public key file from a running SSH server
with the <span class="command"><strong>ssh-keyscan

Name: programs.ssh.knownHostsFiles

<code class="literal">/etc/ssh/ssh_known_hosts

Name: programs.ssh.macs
Desc:
Specifies the MAC (message authentication code) algorithms in order of preference. The MAC algorithm is used

Name: programs.ssh.pubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes
