Desc: Whether to enable sslh, protocol demultiplexer.

Name: services.sslh.listenAddresses
Desc: Listening addresses or hostnames.
Type: (list of string) or string convertible to it

Name: services.sslh.method
Desc: The method to use for handling connections:

Name: services.sslh.port
Desc: Listening port.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.sslh.settings
Desc: sslh configuration. See <span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">sslh

Name: services.sslh.settings.numeric
Desc:
Whether to disable reverse DNS lookups, thus keeping IP
address literals in the log.

Name: services.sslh.settings.protocols
Desc:
List of protocols sslh will probe for and redirect.
Each protocol entry consists of:
Type: list of attribute set of (libconfig value)

Name: services.sslh.settings.timeout
Desc: Timeout in seconds.

Name: services.sslh.settings.transparent
Desc:
Whether the services behind sslh (Apache, sshd and so on) will see the
external IP and ports as if the external world connected directly to
them.

Name: services.sslh.settings.verbose-connections
Desc: Where to log connections information. Possible values are:

Name: services.sslmate-agent.enable
Desc: Whether to enable sslmate-agent, a daemon for managing SSL/TLS certificates on a server.

Name: services.sssd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the System Security Services Daemon.

Name: services.sssd.config
Desc: Contents of <code class="filename">sssd.conf

Name: services.sssd.environmentFile
Desc: Environment file as defined in <a class="link" href="https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.exec.html" target="_top"><span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">systemd.exec

Name: services.sssd.kcm
Desc:
Whether to use SSS as a Kerberos Cache Manager (KCM).
Kerberos will be configured to cache credentials in SSS.

Name: services.sssd.sshAuthorizedKeysIntegration
Desc:
Whether to make sshd look up authorized keys from SSS.
For this to work, the <code class="literal">ssh

Name: services.stalwart-mail.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the Stalwart all-in-one email server.

Name: services.stalwart-mail.package
Desc: The stalwart-mail package to use.

Name: services.stalwart-mail.openFirewall
Desc:
Whether to open TCP firewall ports, which are specified in
<code class="option">services.stalwart-mail.settings.listener

Name: services.stalwart-mail.settings
Desc:
Configuration options for the Stalwart email server.
See <a class="link" href="https://stalw.art/docs/category/configuration"  target="_top">https://stalw.art/docs/category/configuration

Name: services.stargazer.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Stargazer Gemini server.

Name: services.stargazer.allowCgiUser
Desc: When enabled, the stargazer process will be given <code class="literal">CAP_SETGID

Name: services.stargazer.certLifetime
Desc:
How long certs generated by Stargazer should live for.
Certs live forever by default.

Name: services.stargazer.certOrg
Desc:
The name of the organization responsible for the X.509
certificate’s /O name.

Name: services.stargazer.connectionLogging
Desc: Whether or not to log connections to stdout.

Name: services.stargazer.debugMode
Desc: Run Stargazer in debug mode.

Name: services.stargazer.genCerts
Desc:
Set to false to disable automatic certificate generation.
Use if you want to provide your own certs.

Name: services.stargazer.group
Desc: Group account under which stargazer runs.

Name: services.stargazer.ipLog
Desc: Log client IP addresses in the connection log.

Name: services.stargazer.ipLogPartial
Desc: Log partial client IP addresses in the connection log.

Name: services.stargazer.listen
Desc: Address and port to listen on.

Name: services.stargazer.regenCerts
Desc:
Set to false to turn off automatic regeneration of expired certificates.
Use if you want to provide your own certs.

Name: services.stargazer.requestTimeout
Desc:
Number of seconds to wait for the client to send a complete
request. Set to 0 to disable.

Name: services.stargazer.responseTimeout
Desc:
Number of seconds to wait for the client to send a complete
request and for stargazer to finish sending the response.
Set to 0 to disable.

Name: services.stargazer.routes
Desc: Routes that Stargazer should server.
Type: list of (attribute set of (INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string)))

Name: services.stargazer.routes._.route
Desc: Route section name

Name: services.stargazer.store
Desc:
Path to the certificate store on disk. This should be a
persistent directory writable by Stargazer.

Name: services.stargazer.user
Desc: User account under which stargazer runs.

Name: services.static-web-server.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Static Web Server.

Name: services.static-web-server.configuration
Desc:
Configuration for Static Web Server. See
<a class="link" href="https://static-web-server.net/configuration/config-file/"  target="_top">https://static-web-server.net/configuration/config-file/

Name: services.static-web-server.listen
Desc:
The “ListenStream” used in static-web-server.socket.
This is equivalent to SWS’s “host” and “port” options.
See here for specific syntax: <a class="link" href="https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.socket.html#ListenStream="  target="_top">https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.socket.html#ListenStream=

Name: services.static-web-server.root
Desc:
The location of files for SWS to serve. Equivalent to SWS’s “root” config value.
NOTE: This folder must exist before starting SWS.

Name: services.statsd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable statsd.

Name: services.statsd.backends
Desc: List of backends statsd will use for data persistence

Name: services.statsd.extraConfig
Desc: Extra configuration options for statsd

Name: services.statsd.graphiteHost
Desc: Hostname or IP of Graphite server

Name: services.statsd.graphitePort
Desc: Port of Graphite server (i.e. carbon-cache).

Name: services.statsd.listenAddress
Desc: Address that statsd listens on over UDP

Name: services.statsd.mgmt_address
Desc: Address to run management TCP interface on

Name: services.statsd.mgmt_port
Desc: Port to run the management TCP interface on

Name: services.statsd.port
Desc: Port that stats listens for messages on over UDP

Name: services.step-ca.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the smallstep certificate authority server.

Name: services.step-ca.package
Desc: Which step-ca package to use.

Name: services.step-ca.address
Desc:
The address (without port) the certificate authority should listen at.
This combined with <code class="option">services.step-ca.port

Name: services.step-ca.intermediatePasswordFile
Desc:
Path to the file containing the password for the intermediate
certificate private key.

Name: services.step-ca.openFirewall
Desc: Whether to enable opening the certificate authority server port.

Name: services.step-ca.port
Desc:
The port the certificate authority should listen on.
This combined with <code class="option">services.step-ca.address
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.step-ca.settings
Desc: Settings that go into <code class="filename">ca.json

Name: services.stirling-pdf.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the stirling-pdf service.

Name: services.stirling-pdf.package
Desc: The stirling-pdf package to use.

Name: services.stirling-pdf.environment
Desc:
Environment variables for the stirling-pdf app.
See https://github.com/Stirling-Tools/Stirling-PDF#customisation for available options.
Type: attribute set of (string or signed integer)

Name: services.stirling-pdf.environmentFiles
Desc:
Files containing additional environment variables to pass to Stirling PDF.
Secrets should be added in environmentFiles instead of environment.

Name: services.stratis.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Stratis Storage - Easy to use local storage management for Linux.

Name: services.strongswan.enable
Desc: Whether to enable strongSwan.

Name: services.strongswan.enabledPlugins
Desc:
A list of additional plugins to enable if
<code class="option">managePlugins

Name: services.strongswan.ca
Desc:
A set of CAs (certification authorities) and their options for
the ‘ca xxx’ sections of the <code class="filename">ipsec.conf
Type: attribute set of attribute set of string

Name: services.strongswan.connections
Desc:
A set of connections and their options for the ‘conn xxx’
sections of the <code class="filename">ipsec.conf
Type: attribute set of attribute set of string

Name: services.strongswan.managePlugins
Desc:
If set to true, this option will disable automatic plugin loading and
then tell strongSwan to enable the plugins specified in the
<code class="option">enabledPlugins

Name: services.strongswan.secrets
Desc:
A list of paths to IPSec secret files. These
files will be included into the main ipsec.secrets file with
the <code class="literal">include

Name: services.strongswan.setup
Desc:
A set of options for the ‘config setup’ section of the
<code class="filename">ipsec.conf

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.enable
Desc: Whether to enable strongswan-swanctl service.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.package
Desc: The strongswan package to use.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.includes
Desc: Extra configuration files to include in the swanctl configuration. This can be used to provide secret values from outside the nix store.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.strongswan.extraConfig
Desc: Contents of the <code class="literal">strongswan.conf

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities
Desc:
Section defining complementary attributes of certification authorities, each
in its own subsection with an arbitrary yet unique name

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.cacert
Desc:
The certificates may use a relative path from the swanctl
<code class="literal">x509ca

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.cert_uri_base
Desc:
Defines the base URI for the Hash and URL feature supported by
IKEv2. Instead of exchanging complete certificates, IKEv2 allows one to
send an URI that resolves to the DER encoded certificate. The certificate
URIs are built by appending the SHA1 hash of the DER encoded certificates
to this base URI.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.crl_uris
Desc: List of CRL distribution points (ldap, http, or file URI).

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.file
Desc:
Absolute path to the certificate to load. Passed as-is to the daemon, so
it must be readable by it.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.handle
Desc:
Hex-encoded CKA_ID or handle of the certificate on a token or TPM,
respectively.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.module
Desc: Optional PKCS#11 module name.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.ocsp_uris
Desc: List of OCSP URIs.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.authorities._name_.slot
Desc: Optional slot number of the token that stores the certificate.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections
Desc:
Section defining IKE connection configurations, each in its own subsection
with an arbitrary yet unique name

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.aggressive
Desc:
Enables Aggressive Mode instead of Main Mode with Identity
Protection. Aggressive Mode is considered less secure, because the ID and
HASH payloads are exchanged unprotected. This allows a passive attacker to
snoop peer identities, and even worse, start dictionary attacks on the
Preshared Key.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.childless
Desc: Use childless IKE_SA initiation (<span class="emphasis"><em>allow

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children
Desc:
CHILD_SA configuration sub-section. Each connection definition may have
one or more sections in its <code class="option">children

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.ah_proposals
Desc:
AH proposals to offer for the CHILD_SA. A proposal is a set of
algorithms. For AH, this includes an integrity algorithm and an optional
Diffie-Hellman group. If a DH group is specified, CHILD_SA/Quick Mode
rekeying and initial negotiation uses a separate Diffie-Hellman exchange
using the specified group (refer to esp_proposals for details).

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.close_action
Desc: Action to perform after a CHILD_SA gets closed by the peer.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.copy_df
Desc:
Whether to copy the DF bit to the outer IPv4 header in tunnel mode. This
effectively disables Path MTU discovery (PMTUD). Controlling this
behavior is not supported by all kernel interfaces.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.copy_dscp
Desc:
Whether to copy the DSCP (Differentiated Services Field Codepoint)
header field to/from the outer IP header in tunnel mode. The value
<code class="literal">out

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.copy_ecn
Desc:
Whether to copy the ECN (Explicit Congestion Notification) header field
to/from the outer IP header in tunnel mode. Controlling this behavior is
not supported by all kernel interfaces.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.dpd_action
Desc:
Action to perform for this CHILD_SA on DPD timeout. The default clear
closes the CHILD_SA and does not take further action. trap installs a
trap policy, which will catch matching traffic and tries to re-negotiate
the tunnel on-demand. restart immediately tries to re-negotiate the
CHILD_SA under a fresh IKE_SA.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.esp_proposals
Desc:
ESP proposals to offer for the CHILD_SA. A proposal is a set of
algorithms. For ESP non-AEAD proposals, this includes an integrity
algorithm, an encryption algorithm, an optional Diffie-Hellman group and
an optional Extended Sequence Number Mode indicator. For AEAD proposals,
a combined mode algorithm is used instead of the separate
encryption/integrity algorithms.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.hostaccess
Desc: Hostaccess variable to pass to <code class="literal">updown

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.hw_offload
Desc:
Enable hardware offload for this CHILD_SA, if supported by the IPsec
implementation. The values <code class="literal">crypto

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.if_id_in
Desc:
XFRM interface ID set on inbound policies/SA. This allows installing
duplicate policies/SAs and associates them with an interface with the
same ID. The special value <code class="literal">%unique

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.if_id_out
Desc:
XFRM interface ID set on outbound policies/SA. This allows installing
duplicate policies/SAs and associates them with an interface with the
same ID. The special value <code class="literal">%unique

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.inactivity
Desc:
Timeout before closing CHILD_SA after inactivity. If no traffic has been
processed in either direction for the configured timeout, the CHILD_SA
gets closed due to inactivity. The default value of 0 disables inactivity
checks.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.interface
Desc: Optional interface name to restrict outbound IPsec policies.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.ipcomp
Desc:
Enable IPComp compression before encryption. If enabled, IKE tries to
negotiate IPComp compression to compress ESP payload data prior to
encryption.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.life_bytes
Desc:
Maximum bytes processed before CHILD_SA gets closed. Usually this hard
volume limit is never reached, because the CHILD_SA gets rekeyed
before. If that fails for whatever reason, this limit closes the
CHILD_SA.  The default is 10% more than <code class="option">rekey_bytes

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.life_packets
Desc:
Maximum number of packets processed before CHILD_SA gets closed. Usually
this hard packets limit is never reached, because the CHILD_SA gets
rekeyed before. If that fails for whatever reason, this limit closes the
CHILD_SA.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.life_time
Desc:
Maximum lifetime before CHILD_SA gets closed. Usually this hard lifetime
is never reached, because the CHILD_SA gets rekeyed before. If that fails
for whatever reason, this limit closes the CHILD_SA.  The default is 10%
more than the <code class="option">rekey_time

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.local_ts
Desc:
List of local traffic selectors to include in CHILD_SA. Each selector is
a CIDR subnet definition, followed by an optional proto/port
selector. The special value <code class="literal">dynamic

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.mark_in
Desc:
Netfilter mark and mask for input traffic. On Linux, Netfilter may
require marks on each packet to match an SA/policy having that option
set. This allows installing duplicate policies and enables Netfilter
rules to select specific SAs/policies for incoming traffic. Note that
inbound marks are only set on policies, by default, unless
<code class="option">mark_in_sa

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.mark_in_sa
Desc: Whether to set <code class="option">mark_in

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.mark_out
Desc:
Netfilter mark and mask for output traffic. On Linux, Netfilter may
require marks on each packet to match a policy/SA having that option
set. This allows installing duplicate policies and enables Netfilter
rules to select specific policies/SAs for outgoing traffic. The special
value <code class="literal">%unique

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.mode
Desc: IPsec Mode to establish CHILD_SA with.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.policies
Desc:
Whether to install IPsec policies or not. Disabling this can be useful in
some scenarios e.g. MIPv6, where policies are not managed by the IKE
daemon. Since 5.3.3.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.policies_fwd_out
Desc:
Whether to install outbound FWD IPsec policies or not. Enabling this is
required in case there is a drop policy that would match and block
forwarded traffic for this CHILD_SA. Since 5.5.1.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.priority
Desc:
Optional fixed priority for IPsec policies. This could be useful to
install high-priority drop policies. The default of 0 uses dynamically
calculated priorities based on the size of the traffic selectors.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.rand_bytes
Desc:
Byte range from which to choose a random value to subtract from
<code class="option">rekey_bytes

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.rand_packets
Desc:
Packet range from which to choose a random value to subtract from
<code class="option">rekey_packets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.rand_time
Desc:
Time range from which to choose a random value to subtract from
<code class="option">rekey_time

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.rekey_bytes
Desc:
Number of bytes processed before initiating CHILD_SA rekeying. CHILD_SA
rekeying refreshes key material, optionally using a Diffie-Hellman
exchange if a group is specified in the proposal.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.rekey_packets
Desc:
Number of packets processed before initiating CHILD_SA rekeying. CHILD_SA
rekeying refreshes key material, optionally using a Diffie-Hellman
exchange if a group is specified in the proposal.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.rekey_time
Desc:
Time to schedule CHILD_SA rekeying. CHILD_SA rekeying refreshes key
material, optionally using a Diffie-Hellman exchange if a group is
specified in the proposal.  To avoid rekey collisions initiated by both
ends simultaneously, a value in the range of <code class="option">rand_time

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.remote_ts
Desc:
List of remote selectors to include in CHILD_SA. See
<code class="option">local_ts

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.replay_window
Desc:
IPsec replay window to configure for this CHILD_SA. Larger values than
the default of <code class="literal">32

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.reqid
Desc:
Fixed reqid to use for this CHILD_SA. This might be helpful in some
scenarios, but works only if each CHILD_SA configuration is instantiated
not more than once. The default of 0 uses dynamic reqids, allocated
incrementally.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.set_mark_in
Desc:
Netfilter mark applied to packets after the inbound IPsec SA processed
them. This way it’s not necessary to mark packets via Netfilter before
decryption or right afterwards to match policies or process them
differently (e.g. via policy routing).

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.set_mark_out
Desc:
Netfilter mark applied to packets after the outbound IPsec SA processed
them. This allows processing ESP packets differently than the original
traffic (e.g. via policy routing).

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.sha256_96
Desc:
HMAC-SHA-256 is used with 128-bit truncation with IPsec. For
compatibility with implementations that incorrectly use 96-bit truncation
this option may be enabled to configure the shorter truncation length in
the kernel. This is not negotiated, so this only works with peers that
use the incorrect truncation length (or have this option enabled).

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.start_action
Desc: Action to perform after loading the configuration.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.tfc_padding
Desc:
Pads ESP packets with additional data to have a consistent ESP packet
size for improved Traffic Flow Confidentiality. The padding defines the
minimum size of all ESP packets sent.  The default value of
<code class="literal">0
Type: null or signed integer or value “mtu” (singular enum)

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.children._name_.updown
Desc: Updown script to invoke on CHILD_SA up and down events.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.dpd_delay
Desc:
Interval to check the liveness of a peer actively using IKEv2
INFORMATIONAL exchanges or IKEv1 R_U_THERE messages. Active DPD checking
is only enforced if no IKE or ESP/AH packet has been received for the
configured DPD delay.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.dpd_timeout
Desc:
Charon by default uses the normal retransmission mechanism and timeouts to
check the liveness of a peer, as all messages are used for liveness
checking. For compatibility reasons, with IKEv1 a custom interval may be
specified; this option has no effect on connections using IKEv2.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.dscp
Desc:
Differentiated Services Field Codepoint to set on outgoing IKE packets for
this connection. The value is a six digit binary encoded string specifying
the Codepoint to set, as defined in RFC 2474.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.encap
Desc:
To enforce UDP encapsulation of ESP packets, the IKE daemon can fake the
NAT detection payloads. This makes the peer believe that NAT takes place
on the path, forcing it to encapsulate ESP packets in UDP.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.fragmentation
Desc:
Use IKE fragmentation (proprietary IKEv1 extension or RFC 7383 IKEv2
fragmentation). Acceptable values are <code class="literal">yes

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.if_id_in
Desc:
XFRM interface ID set on inbound policies/SA, can be overridden by child
config, see there for details.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.if_id_out
Desc:
XFRM interface ID set on outbound policies/SA, can be overridden by child
config, see there for details.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.keyingtries
Desc:
Number of retransmission sequences to perform during initial
connect. Instead of giving up initiation after the first retransmission
sequence with the default value of <code class="literal">1

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local
Desc:
Section for a local authentication round. A local authentication round
defines the rules how authentication is performed for the local
peer. Multiple rounds may be defined to use IKEv2 RFC 4739 Multiple
Authentication or IKEv1 XAuth.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.aaa_id
Desc:
Server side EAP-Identity to expect in the EAP method. Some EAP methods,
such as EAP-TLS, use an identity for the server to perform mutual
authentication. This identity may differ from the IKE identity,
especially when EAP authentication is delegated from the IKE responder
to an AAA backend.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.auth
Desc: Authentication to perform locally.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.cert
Desc:
Section for a certificate candidate to use for
authentication. Certificates in certs are transmitted as binary blobs,
these sections offer more flexibility.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.cert._name_.file
Desc:
Absolute path to the certificate to load. Passed as-is to the daemon, so
it must be readable by it.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.cert._name_.handle
Desc:
Hex-encoded CKA_ID or handle of the certificate on a token or TPM,
respectively.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.cert._name_.module
Desc: Optional PKCS#11 module name.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.cert._name_.slot
Desc: Optional slot number of the token that stores the certificate.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.certs
Desc:
List of certificate candidates to use for
authentication. The certificates may use a relative path from the
swanctl <code class="literal">x509

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.eap_id
Desc: Client EAP-Identity to use in EAP-Identity exchange and the EAP method.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.id
Desc:
IKE identity to use for authentication round. When using certificate
authentication, the IKE identity must be contained in the certificate,
either as subject or as subjectAltName.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.pubkeys
Desc:
List of raw public key candidates to use for
authentication. The public keys may use a relative path from the swanctl
<code class="literal">pubkey

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.round
Desc:
Optional numeric identifier by which authentication rounds are
sorted. If not specified rounds are ordered by their position in the
config file/vici message.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local._name_.xauth_id
Desc: Client XAuth username used in the XAuth exchange.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local_addrs
Desc:
Local address(es) to use for IKE communication. Takes
single IPv4/IPv6 addresses, DNS names, CIDR subnets or IP address ranges.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.local_port
Desc:
Local UDP port for IKE communication. By default the port of the socket
backend is used, which is usually <code class="literal">500

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.mediated_by
Desc:
The name of the connection to mediate this connection through. If given,
the connection will be mediated through the named mediation
connection. The mediation connection must have mediation enabled.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.mediation
Desc:
Whether this connection is a mediation connection, that is, whether this
connection is used to mediate other connections using the IKEv2 Mediation
Extension. Mediation connections create no CHILD_SA.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.mediation_peer
Desc:
Identity under which the peer is registered at the mediation server, that
is, the IKE identity the other end of this connection uses as its local
identity on its connection to the mediation server. This is the identity
we request the mediation server to mediate us with. Only relevant on
connections that set mediated_by. If it is not given, the remote IKE
identity of the first authentication round of this connection will be
used.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.mobike
Desc:
Enables MOBIKE on IKEv2 connections. MOBIKE is enabled by default on IKEv2
connections, and allows mobility of clients and multi-homing on servers by
migrating active IPsec tunnels.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.over_time
Desc:
Hard IKE_SA lifetime if rekey/reauth does not complete, as time. To avoid
having an IKE/ISAKMP kept alive if IKE reauthentication or rekeying fails
perpetually, a maximum hard lifetime may be specified. If the IKE_SA fails
to rekey or reauthenticate within the specified time, the IKE_SA gets
closed.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.pools
Desc:
List of named IP pools to allocate virtual IP addresses
and other configuration attributes from. Each name references a pool by
name from either the pools section or an external pool.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.ppk_id
Desc: String identifying the Postquantum Preshared Key (PPK) to be used.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.ppk_required
Desc: Whether a Postquantum Preshared Key (PPK) is required for this connection.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.proposals
Desc:
A proposal is a set of algorithms. For non-AEAD algorithms, this includes
for IKE an encryption algorithm, an integrity algorithm, a pseudo random
function and a Diffie-Hellman group. For AEAD algorithms, instead of
encryption and integrity algorithms, a combined algorithm is used.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.pull
Desc:
If the default of yes is used, Mode Config works in pull mode, where the
initiator actively requests a virtual IP. With no, push mode is used,
where the responder pushes down a virtual IP to the initiating peer.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.rand_time
Desc:
Time range from which to choose a random value to subtract from
rekey/reauth times. To avoid having both peers initiating the rekey/reauth
procedure simultaneously, a random time gets subtracted from the
rekey/reauth times.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.reauth_time
Desc:
Time to schedule IKE reauthentication. IKE reauthentication recreates the
IKE/ISAKMP SA from scratch and re-evaluates the credentials. In asymmetric
configurations (with EAP or configuration payloads) it might not be
possible to actively reauthenticate as responder. The IKEv2
reauthentication lifetime negotiation can instruct the client to perform
reauthentication.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.rekey_time
Desc:
IKE rekeying refreshes key material using a Diffie-Hellman exchange, but
does not re-check associated credentials. It is supported in IKEv2 only,
IKEv1 performs a reauthentication procedure instead.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote
Desc:
Section for a remote authentication round. A remote authentication round
defines the constraints how the peers must authenticate to use this
connection. Multiple rounds may be defined to use IKEv2 RFC 4739 Multiple
Authentication or IKEv1 XAuth.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.auth
Desc: Authentication to expect from remote. See the <code class="option">local

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.ca_id
Desc:
Identity in CA certificate to accept for authentication. The specified
identity must be contained in one (intermediate) CA of the remote peer
trustchain, either as subject or as subjectAltName. This has the same
effect as specifying <code class="literal">cacerts

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cacert
Desc:
Section for a CA certificate to accept for authentication. Certificates
in cacerts are transmitted as binary blobs, these sections offer more
flexibility.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cacert._name_.file
Desc:
Absolute path to the certificate to load. Passed as-is to the daemon, so
it must be readable by it.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cacert._name_.handle
Desc:
Hex-encoded CKA_ID or handle of the certificate on a token or TPM,
respectively.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cacert._name_.module
Desc: Optional PKCS#11 module name.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cacert._name_.slot
Desc: Optional slot number of the token that stores the certificate.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cacerts
Desc:
List of CA certificates to accept for
authentication. The certificates may use a relative path from the
swanctl <code class="literal">x509ca

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cert
Desc:
Section for a certificate candidate to use for
authentication. Certificates in certs are transmitted as binary blobs,
these sections offer more flexibility.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cert._name_.file
Desc:
Absolute path to the certificate to load. Passed as-is to the daemon, so
it must be readable by it.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cert._name_.handle
Desc:
Hex-encoded CKA_ID or handle of the certificate on a token or TPM,
respectively.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cert._name_.module
Desc: Optional PKCS#11 module name.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cert._name_.slot
Desc: Optional slot number of the token that stores the certificate.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.cert_policy
Desc:
List of certificate policy OIDs the peer’s certificate
must have. OIDs are specified using the numerical dotted representation.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.certs
Desc:
List of certificates to accept for authentication. The certificates may
use a relative path from the swanctl <code class="literal">x509

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.eap_id
Desc:
Identity to use as peer identity during EAP authentication. If set to
<code class="literal">%any

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.groups
Desc:
Authorization group memberships to require. The peer
must prove membership to at least one of the specified groups. Group
membership can be certified by different means, for example by
appropriate Attribute Certificates or by an AAA backend involved in the
authentication.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.id
Desc:
IKE identity to expect for authentication round. When using certificate
authentication, the IKE identity must be contained in the certificate,
either as subject or as subjectAltName.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.pubkeys
Desc:
List of raw public keys to accept for
authentication. The public keys may use a relative path from the swanctl
<code class="literal">pubkey

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.revocation
Desc: Certificate revocation policy for CRL or OCSP revocation.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote._name_.round
Desc:
Optional numeric identifier by which authentication rounds are
sorted. If not specified rounds are ordered by their position in the
config file/vici message.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote_addrs
Desc:
Remote address(es) to use for IKE communication. Takes
single IPv4/IPv6 addresses, DNS names, CIDR subnets or IP address ranges.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.remote_port
Desc:
Remote UDP port for IKE communication. If the default of port
<code class="literal">500

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.send_cert
Desc: Send certificate payloads when using certificate authentication.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.send_certreq
Desc:
Send certificate request payloads to offer trusted root CA certificates to
the peer. Certificate requests help the peer to choose an appropriate
certificate/private key for authentication and are enabled by default.
Disabling certificate requests can be useful if too many trusted root CA
certificates are installed, as each certificate request increases the size
of the initial IKE packets.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.unique
Desc:
Connection uniqueness policy to enforce. To avoid multiple connections
from the same user, a uniqueness policy can be enforced.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.version
Desc: IKE major version to use for connection.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.connections._name_.vips
Desc:
List of virtual IPs to request in IKEv2 configuration payloads or IKEv1
Mode Config. The wildcard addresses <code class="literal">0.0.0.0

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools
Desc:
Section defining named pools. Named pools may be referenced by connections
with the pools option to assign virtual IPs and other configuration
attributes. Each pool must have a unique name (denoted <name> below).

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.addrs
Desc:
Subnet or range defining addresses allocated in pool. Accepts a single
CIDR subnet defining the pool to allocate addresses from or an address
range (<from>-<to>). Pools must be unique and non-overlapping.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.dhcp
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.dns
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.nbns
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.netmask
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.server
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.split_exclude
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.split_include
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.pools._name_.subnet
Desc: Address or CIDR subnets

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.eap
Desc:
EAP secret section for a specific secret. Each EAP secret is defined in a
unique section having the <code class="literal">eap

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.eap._name_.id
Desc:
Identity the EAP/XAuth secret belongs to. Multiple unique identities may
be specified, each having an <code class="literal">id

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.eap._name_.secret
Desc:
Value of the EAP/XAuth secret. It may either be an ASCII string, a hex
encoded string if it has a 0x prefix or a Base64 encoded string if it
has a 0s prefix in its value.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ecdsa
Desc:
Private key decryption passphrase for a key in the
<code class="literal">ecdsa

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ecdsa._name_.file
Desc: File name in the <code class="literal">ecdsa

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ecdsa._name_.secret
Desc: Value of decryption passphrase for ECDSA key.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ike
Desc:
IKE preshared secret section for a specific secret. Each IKE PSK is
defined in a unique section having the <code class="literal">ike

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ike._name_.id
Desc:
IKE identity the IKE preshared secret belongs to. Multiple unique
identities may be specified, each having an <code class="literal">id

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ike._name_.secret
Desc:
Value of the IKE preshared secret. It may either be an ASCII string, a
hex encoded string if it has a 0x prefix or a Base64 encoded string if
it has a 0s prefix in its value.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ntlm
Desc:
NTLM secret section for a specific secret. Each NTLM secret is defined in
a unique section having the <code class="literal">ntlm

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ntlm._name_.id
Desc:
Identity the NTLM secret belongs to. Multiple unique identities may be
specified, each having an id prefix, if a secret is shared between
multiple users.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ntlm._name_.secret
Desc:
Value of the NTLM secret, which is the NT Hash of the actual secret,
that is, MD4(UTF-16LE(secret)). The resulting 16-byte value may either
be given as a hex encoded string with a 0x prefix or as a Base64 encoded
string with a 0s prefix.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.pkcs12
Desc:
PKCS#12 decryption passphrase for a container in the
<code class="literal">pkcs12

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.pkcs12._name_.file
Desc: File name in the <code class="literal">pkcs12

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.pkcs12._name_.secret
Desc: Value of decryption passphrase for PKCS#12 container.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.pkcs8
Desc:
Private key decryption passphrase for a key in the
<code class="literal">pkcs8

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.pkcs8._name_.file
Desc: File name in the <code class="literal">pkcs8

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.pkcs8._name_.secret
Desc: Value of decryption passphrase for PKCS#8 key.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ppk
Desc:
Postquantum Preshared Key (PPK) section for a specific secret. Each PPK is
defined in a unique section having the <code class="literal">ppk

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ppk._name_.id
Desc:
PPK identity the PPK belongs to. Multiple unique identities may be
specified, each having an <code class="literal">id

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.ppk._name_.secret
Desc:
Value of the PPK. It may either be an ASCII string, a hex encoded string
if it has a <code class="literal">0x

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.private
Desc:
Private key decryption passphrase for a key in the
<code class="literal">private

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.private._name_.file
Desc: File name in the private folder for which this passphrase should be used.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.private._name_.secret
Desc: Value of decryption passphrase for private key.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.rsa
Desc: Private key decryption passphrase for a key in the <code class="literal">rsa

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.rsa._name_.file
Desc: File name in the <code class="literal">rsa

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.rsa._name_.secret
Desc: Value of decryption passphrase for RSA key.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.token
Desc: Definition for a private key that’s stored on a token/smartcard/TPM.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.token._name_.handle
Desc:
Hex-encoded CKA_ID or handle of the private key on the token or TPM,
respectively.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.token._name_.module
Desc: Optional PKCS#11 module name to access the token.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.token._name_.pin
Desc:
Optional PIN required to access the key on the token. If none is
provided the user is prompted during an interactive
<code class="literal">--load-creds

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.token._name_.slot
Desc: Optional slot number to access the token.

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.xauth
Desc:
EAP secret section for a specific secret. Each EAP secret is defined in a
unique section having the <code class="literal">eap

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.xauth._name_.id
Desc:
Identity the EAP/XAuth secret belongs to. Multiple unique identities may
be specified, each having an <code class="literal">id

Name: services.strongswan-swanctl.swanctl.secrets.xauth._name_.secret
Desc:
Value of the EAP/XAuth secret. It may either be an ASCII string, a hex
encoded string if it has a 0x prefix or a Base64 encoded string if it
has a 0s prefix in its value.

Name: services.stubby.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Stubby DNS resolver.

Name: services.stubby.logLevel
Desc: Log verbosity (syslog keyword or level).

Name: services.stubby.settings
Desc:
Content of the Stubby configuration file. All Stubby settings may be set or queried
here. The default settings are available at
<code class="literal">pkgs.stubby.passthru.settingsExample

Name: services.stunnel.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the stunnel TLS tunneling service.

Name: services.stunnel.enableInsecureSSLv3
Desc: Enable support for the insecure SSLv3 protocol.

Name: services.stunnel.clients
Desc: Define the client configurations.
Type: attribute set of attribute set of (null or boolean or signed integer or string)

Name: services.stunnel.fipsMode
Desc: Enable FIPS 140-2 mode required for compliance.

Name: services.stunnel.group
Desc: The group under which stunnel runs.

Name: services.stunnel.logLevel
Desc: Verbosity of stunnel output.

Name: services.stunnel.servers
Desc: Define the server configurations.
Type: attribute set of attribute set of (null or boolean or signed integer or string)

Name: services.stunnel.user
Desc: The user under which stunnel runs.

Name: services.subsonic.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Subsonic daemon.

Name: services.subsonic.contextPath
Desc:
The context path, i.e., the last part of the Subsonic
URL. Typically ‘/’ or ‘/subsonic’. Default ‘/’

Name: services.subsonic.defaultMusicFolder
Desc:
Configure Subsonic to use this folder for music.  This option
only has effect the first time Subsonic is started.

Name: services.subsonic.defaultPlaylistFolder
Desc:
Configure Subsonic to use this folder for playlists.  This option
only has effect the first time Subsonic is started.

Name: services.subsonic.defaultPodcastFolder
Desc:
Configure Subsonic to use this folder for Podcasts.  This option
only has effect the first time Subsonic is started.

Name: services.subsonic.home
Desc:
The directory where Subsonic will create files.
Make sure it is writable.

Name: services.subsonic.httpsPort
Desc:
The port on which Subsonic will listen for
incoming HTTPS traffic. Set to 0 to disable.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.subsonic.listenAddress
Desc:
The host name or IP address on which to bind Subsonic.
Only relevant if you have multiple network interfaces and want
to make Subsonic available on only one of them. The default value
will bind Subsonic to all available network interfaces.

Name: services.subsonic.maxMemory
Desc:
The memory limit (max Java heap size) in megabytes.
Default: 100

Name: services.subsonic.port
Desc:
The port on which Subsonic will listen for
incoming HTTP traffic. Set to 0 to disable.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.subsonic.transcoders
Desc:
List of paths to transcoder executables that should be accessible
from Subsonic. Symlinks will be created to each executable inside
${config.services.subsonic.home}/transcoders.

Name: services.sundtek.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Sundtek driver.

Name: services.sunshine.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Sunshine, a self-hosted game stream host for Moonlight.

Name: services.sunshine.package
Desc: The sunshine package to use.

Name: services.sunshine.applications
Desc: Configuration for applications to be exposed to Moonlight. If this is set, no configuration is possible from the web UI, and must be by the <code class="literal">settings

Name: services.sunshine.applications.apps
Desc: Applications to be exposed to Moonlight.

Name: services.sunshine.applications.env
Desc: Environment variables to be set for the applications.

Name: services.sunshine.autoStart
Desc: Whether sunshine should be started automatically.

Name: services.sunshine.capSysAdmin
Desc: Whether to give the Sunshine binary CAP_SYS_ADMIN, required for DRM/KMS screen capture.

Name: services.sunshine.openFirewall
Desc: Whether to automatically open ports in the firewall.

Name: services.sunshine.settings
Desc: Settings to be rendered into the configuration file. If this is set, no configuration is possible from the web UI.
Type: attribute set of (atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

Name: services.sunshine.settings.port
Desc: Base port – others used are offset from this one, see https://docs.lizardbyte.dev/projects/sunshine/en/latest/about/advanced_usage.html#port for details.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.supergfxd.enable
Desc: Whether to enable the supergfxd service.

Name: services.supergfxd.settings
Desc:
The content of /etc/supergfxd.conf.
See https://gitlab.com/asus-linux/supergfxctl/#config-options-etcsupergfxdconf.

Name: services.supybot.enable
Desc: Enable Supybot, an IRC bot (also known as Limnoria).

Name: services.supybot.configFile
Desc:
Path to initial supybot config file. This can be generated by
running supybot-wizard.

Name: services.supybot.extraPackages
Desc:
Extra Python packages available to supybot plugins. The
value must be a function which receives the attrset defined
in <code class="varname">python3Packages
Type: function that evaluates to a(n) list of package

Name: services.supybot.plugins
Desc:
Attribute set of additional plugins that will be symlinked to the
<code class="filename">plugin

Name: services.supybot.stateDir
Desc: The root directory, logs and plugins are stored here

Name: services.suricata.enable
Desc: Whether to enable Suricata.

Name: services.suricata.enabledSources
Desc:
List of sources that should be enabled.
Currently sources which require a secret-code are not supported.

Name: services.suricata.package
Desc: The suricata package to use.

Name: services.suricata.disabledRules
Desc: List of rules that should be disabled.

Name: services.suricata.settings
Desc: Suricata settings

Name: services.suricata.settings.af-packet
Desc: Linux high speed capture support.

Name: services.suricata.settings.af-packet._.interface
Desc: af-packet capture interface, see <a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/latest/performance/tuning-considerations.html#af-packet"  target="_top">upstream docs reagrding tuning

Name: services.suricata.settings.af-xdp
Desc:
Linux high speed af-xdp capture support, see
<a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/suricata-7.0.3/capture-hardware/af-xdp.html"  target="_top">docs/capture-hardware/af-xdp

Name: services.suricata.settings.af-xdp._.interface
Desc: af-xdp capture interface, see <a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/latest/capture-hardware/af-xdp.html"  target="_top">upstream docs

Name: services.suricata.settings.app-layer
Desc: app-layer configuration, see <a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/latest/rules/app-layer.html"  target="_top">upstream docs

Name: services.suricata.settings.app-layer.error-policy
Desc:
The error-policy setting applies to all app-layer parsers. Values can be
“drop-flow”, “pass-flow”, “bypass”, “drop-packet”, “pass-packet”, “reject” or
“ignore” (the default).

Name: services.suricata.settings.app-layer.protocols
Desc: app-layer protocols, see <a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/latest/rules/app-layer.html"  target="_top">upstream docs

Name: services.suricata.settings.app-layer.protocols._name_.enabled
Desc:
The option “enabled” takes 3 values - “yes”, “no”, “detection-only”.
“yes” enables both detection and the parser, “no” disables both, and
“detection-only” enables protocol detection only (parser disabled).

Name: services.suricata.settings.classification-file
Desc: Suricata classification configuration file.

Name: services.suricata.settings.default-log-dir
Desc:
The default logging directory. Any log or output file will be placed here if it’s
not specified with a full path name. This can be overridden with the -l command
line parameter.

Name: services.suricata.settings.default-rule-path
Desc: Path in which suricata-update managed rules are stored by default.

Name: services.suricata.settings.dpdk
Desc: Data Plane Development Kit is a framework for fast packet processing in data plane applications running on a wide variety of CPU architectures. DPDK’s Environment Abstraction Layer (EAL) provides a generic interface to low-level resources. It is a unique way how DPDK libraries access NICs. EAL creates an API for an application to access NIC resources from the userspace level. In DPDK, packets are not retrieved via interrupt handling. Instead, the application polls the NIC for newly received packets.

Name: services.suricata.settings.dpdk.eal-params.proc-type
Desc: dpdk eal-params.proc-type, see <a class="link" href="https://doc.dpdk.org/guides/linux_gsg/linux_eal_parameters.html#multiprocessing-related-options"  target="_top">data plane development kit docs

Name: services.suricata.settings.dpdk.interfaces
Desc: See upstream docs: <a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/suricata-7.0.7/capture-hardware/dpdk.html"  target="_top">docs/capture-hardware/dpdk

Name: services.suricata.settings.dpdk.interfaces._.interface
Desc: See upstream docs: <a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/suricata-7.0.7/capture-hardware/dpdk.html"  target="_top">docs/capture-hardware/dpdk

Name: services.suricata.settings.exception-policy
Desc:
Define a common behavior for all exception policies.
In IPS mode, the default is drop-flow. For cases when that’s not possible, the
engine will fall to drop-packet. To fallback to old behavior (setting each of
them individually, or ignoring all), set this to ignore.
All values available for exception policies can be used, and there is one
extra option: auto - which means drop-flow or drop-packet (as explained above)
in IPS mode, and ignore in IDS mode. Exception policy values are: drop-packet,
drop-flow, reject, bypass, pass-packet, pass-flow, ignore (disable).

Name: services.suricata.settings.host-mode
Desc:
If the Suricata box is a router for the sniffed networks, set it to ‘router’. If
it is a pure sniffing setup, set it to ‘sniffer-only’. If set to auto, the variable
is internally switched to ‘router’ in IPS mode and ‘sniffer-only’ in IDS mode.
This feature is currently only used by the reject* keywords.

Name: services.suricata.settings.includes
Desc:
Files to include in the suricata configuration. See
<a class="link" href="https://docs.suricata.io/en/suricata-7.0.3/configuration/suricata-yaml.html"  target="_top">docs/configuration/suricata-yaml

Name: services.suricata.settings.logging.default-log-level
Desc:

Name: services.suricata.settings.logging.default-output-filter
Desc:

Desc:
Config file for swapspace.

Desc: Percentage of buffer space considered to be “free”

Desc:
Duration (roughly in seconds) of the moratorium on swap allocation that is instated if disk space runs out, or the cooldown time after a new swapfile is successfully allocated before swapspace will consider deallocating swap space again.
The default cooldown period is about 10 minutes.

Percentage of free space swapspace should aim for when adding swapspace.

Desc: Lower free-space threshold: if the percentage of free space drops below this number, additional swapspace is allocated

Name: services.swapspace.settings.swappath
Desc: Location where swapspace may create and delete swapfiles

Name: services.swapspace.settings.upper_freelimit
Desc: Upper free-space threshold: if the percentage of free space exceeds this number, swapspace will attempt to free up swapspace

Desc: The device ID. See <a class="link" href="https://docs.syncthing.net/dev/device-ids.html"  target="_top">https://docs.syncthing.net/dev/device-ids.html

Name: services.syncthing.settings.devices._name_.name
Desc: The name of the device.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders
Desc: Folders which should be shared by Syncthing.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.enable
Desc:
Whether to share this folder.
This option is useful when you want to define all folders
in one place, but not every machine should share all folders.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.copyOwnershipFromParent
Desc:
On Unix systems, tries to copy file/folder ownership from the parent directory (the directory it’s located in).
Requires running Syncthing as a privileged user, or granting it additional capabilities (e.g. CAP_CHOWN on Linux).

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.devices
Desc:
The devices this folder should be shared with. Each device must
be defined in the <a class='link' href='/manual/nixos/unstable/options#opt-services.syncthing.settings.devices'>devices

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.id
Desc: The ID of the folder. Must be the same on all devices.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.label
Desc: The label of the folder.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.path
Desc:
The path to the folder which should be shared.
Only absolute paths (starting with <code class="literal">/

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.type
Desc:
Controls how the folder is handled by Syncthing.
See <a class="link" href="https://docs.syncthing.net/users/config.html#config-option-folder.type"  target="_top">https://docs.syncthing.net/users/config.html#config-option-folder.type

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.versioning
Desc:
How to keep changed/deleted files with Syncthing.
There are 4 different types of versioning with different parameters.
See <a class="link" href="https://docs.syncthing.net/users/versioning.html"  target="_top">https://docs.syncthing.net/users/versioning.html

Name: services.syncthing.settings.folders._name_.versioning.type
Desc:
The type of versioning.
See <a class="link" href="https://docs.syncthing.net/users/versioning.html"  target="_top">https://docs.syncthing.net/users/versioning.html

Name: services.syncthing.settings.options
Desc: The options element contains all other global configuration options

Name: services.syncthing.settings.options.limitBandwidthInLan
Desc: Whether to apply bandwidth limits to devices in the same broadcast domain as the local device.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.options.localAnnounceEnabled
Desc: Whether to send announcements to the local LAN, also use such announcements to find other devices.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.options.localAnnouncePort
Desc: The port on which to listen and send IPv4 broadcast announcements to.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.options.maxFolderConcurrency
Desc:
This option controls how many folders may concurrently be in I/O-intensive operations such as syncing or scanning.
The mechanism is described in detail in a <a class="link" href="https://docs.syncthing.net/advanced/option-max-concurrency.html"  target="_top">separate chapter

Name: services.syncthing.settings.options.relaysEnabled
Desc: When true, relays will be connected to and potentially used for device to device connections.

Name: services.syncthing.settings.options.urAccepted
Desc:
Whether the user has accepted to submit anonymous usage data.
The default, 0, mean the user has not made a choice, and Syncthing will ask at some point in the future.
“-1” means no, a number above zero means that that version of usage reporting has been accepted.

Name: services.syncthing.systemService
Desc: Whether to auto-launch Syncthing as a system service.

Name: services.syncthing.user
Desc:
The user to run Syncthing as.

A file containing the auth key.
Tailscale will be automatically started if provided.

Extra parameters to pass after the auth key.
See https://tailscale.com/kb/1215/oauth-clients#registering-new-nodes-using-oauth-credentials

Whether to open the firewall for the specified port.

STUN port to listen on.
See online docs <a class="link" href="https://tailscale.com/kb/1118/custom-derp-servers#prerequisites"  target="_top">https://tailscale.com/kb/1118/custom-derp-servers#prerequisites
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.tarsnap.enable
Desc: Whether to enable periodic tarsnap backups.

Name: services.tarsnap.package
Desc: The tarsnap package to use.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives
Desc:
Tarsnap archive configurations. Each attribute names an archive
to be created at a given time interval, according to the options
associated with it. When uploading to the tarsnap server,
archive names are suffixed by a 1 second resolution timestamp,
with the format <code class="literal">%Y%m%d%H%M%S

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.aggressiveNetworking
Desc:
Upload data over multiple TCP connections, potentially
increasing tarsnap’s bandwidth utilisation at the cost
of slowing down all other network traffic. Not
recommended unless TCP congestion is the dominant
limiting factor.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.cachedir
Desc:
The cache allows tarsnap to identify previously stored data
blocks, reducing archival time and bandwidth usage.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.checkpointBytes
Desc: Create a checkpoint every <code class="literal">checkpointBytes

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.directories
Desc: List of filesystem paths to archive.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.excludes
Desc: Exclude files and directories matching these patterns.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.explicitSymlinks
Desc: Whether to follow symlinks specified as archives.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.followSymlinks
Desc: Whether to follow all symlinks in archive trees.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.includes
Desc:
Include only files and directories matching these
patterns (the empty list includes everything).

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.keyfile
Desc:
Set a specific keyfile for this archive. This defaults to
<code class="literal">"/root/tarsnap.key"

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.lowmem
Desc:
Reduce memory consumption by not caching small files.
Possibly beneficial if the average file size is smaller
than 1 MB and the number of files is lower than the
total amount of RAM in KB.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.maxbw
Desc:
Abort archival if upstream bandwidth usage in bytes
exceeds this threshold.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.maxbwRateDown
Desc: Download bandwidth rate limit in bytes.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.maxbwRateUp
Desc: Upload bandwidth rate limit in bytes.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.nodump
Desc: Exclude files with the <code class="literal">nodump

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.period
Desc: Create archive at this interval.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.printStats
Desc:
Print global archive statistics upon completion.
The output is available via
<span class="command"><strong>systemctl status tarsnap-archive-name

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.verbose
Desc: Whether to produce verbose logging output.

Name: services.tarsnap.archives._name_.verylowmem
Desc:
Reduce memory consumption by a factor of 2 beyond what
<code class="literal">lowmem

Name: services.tarsnap.keyfile
Desc:
The keyfile which associates this machine with your tarsnap
account.
Create the keyfile with <span class="command"><strong>tarsnap-keygen

Name: services.tcsd.enable
Desc:
Whether to enable tcsd, a Trusted Computing management service
that provides TCG Software Stack (TSS).  The tcsd daemon is
the only portal to the Trusted Platform Module (TPM), a hardware
chip on the motherboard.

Name: services.tcsd.conformanceCred
Desc:
Path to the conformance credential for your TPM.
See also the platformCred option

Name: services.tcsd.endorsementCred
Desc:
Path to the endorsement credential for your TPM.
See also the platformCred option

Name: services.tcsd.firmwarePCRs
Desc: PCR indices used in the TPM for firmware measurements.

Name: services.tcsd.group
Desc: Group account under which tcsd runs.

Name: services.tcsd.kernelPCRs
Desc: PCR indices used in the TPM for kernel measurements.

Name: services.tcsd.platformCred
Desc:
Path to the platform credential for your TPM. Your TPM
manufacturer may have provided you with a set of credentials
(certificates) that should be used when creating identities
using your TPM. When a user of your TPM makes an identity,
this credential will be encrypted as part of that process.
See the 1.1b TPM Main specification section 9.3 for information
on this process.

Name: services.tcsd.stateDir
Desc:
The location of the system persistent storage file.
The system persistent storage file holds keys and data across
restarts of the TCSD and system reboots.

Name: services.tcsd.user
Desc: User account under which tcsd runs.

Desc: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming file transfer connections. Defaults to any IP.

Desc: Open ports in the firewall for the TeamSpeak3 server.

Desc: Open ports in the firewall for the TeamSpeak3 serverquery (administration) system. Requires openFirewall.

Desc: TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections using the HTTP protocol.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.teamspeak3.queryIP
Desc: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming ServerQuery connections. Defaults to any IP.

Name: services.teamspeak3.queryPort
Desc: TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections using the raw telnet protocol.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.teamspeak3.querySshPort
Desc: TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections using the SSH protocol.
Type: 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.teamspeak3.voiceIP
Desc: IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming voice connections. Defaults to any IP.

Desc: The technitium-dns-server package to use.

Name: services.technitium-dns-server.firewallTCPPorts
Desc:
List of TCP ports to open in firewall.
You might want to open ports 443 and 853 if you intend to use DNS over HTTPS or DNS over TLS.

Name: services.technitium-dns-server.firewallUDPPorts
Desc: List of UDP ports to open in firewall.

Name: services.technitium-dns-server.openFirewall
Desc:
Whether to open ports in the firewall.
Standard ports are 53 (UDP and TCP, for DNS), 5380 and 53443 (TCP, HTTP and HTTPS for web interface).
Specify different or additional ports in options firewallUDPPorts and firewallTCPPorts if necessary.

A list of values to be added to the temperature of each sensor,

The sensor type, can be

Name: services.tigerbeetle.enable
Desc: Whether to enable TigerBeetle server.

Name: services.tigerbeetle.package
Desc: The tigerbeetle package to use.

Name: services.tigerbeetle.addresses
Desc:
The addresses of all replicas in the cluster.
This should be a list of IPv4/IPv6 addresses with port numbers.
Either the address or port number (but not both) may be omitted, in which case a default of 127.0.0.1 or 3001 will be used.
The first address in the list corresponds to the address for replica 0, the second address for replica 1, and so on.

Name: services.tigerbeetle.cacheGridSize
Desc:
The grid cache size.
The grid cache acts like a page cache for TigerBeetle.
It is recommended to set this as large as possible.

Name: services.tigerbeetle.clusterId
Desc:
The 128-bit cluster ID used to create the replica data file (if needed).
Since Nix only supports integers up to 64 bits, you need to pass a string to this if the cluster ID can’t fit in 64 bits.
Otherwise, you can pass the cluster ID as either an integer or a string.
Type: unsigned integer, meaning >=0, or string matching the pattern [0-9]+

Name: services.tigerbeetle.replicaCount
Desc: The number of replicas participating in replication of the cluster.

Name: services.tigerbeetle.replicaIndex
Desc: The index (starting at 0) of the replica in the cluster.

Defines the tinc networks which will be started.
Each network invokes a different daemon.

Desc:
Change process root directory to the directory where the config file is located (/etc/tinc/netname/), for added security.
The chroot is performed after all the initialization is done, after writing pid files and opening network sockets.

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.debugLevel
Desc:
The amount of debugging information to add to the log. 0 means little
logging while 5 is the most logging. <span class="command"><strong>man tincd

Desc: Extra lines to add to the tinc service configuration file.

Desc:
The name of the host in the network as well as the configuration for that host.
This name should only contain alphanumerics and underscores.

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.hostSettings._name_.addresses
Desc:
The external address where the host can be reached. This will set this

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.hostSettings._name_.addresses._.address
Desc: The external IP address or hostname where the host can be reached.

Desc: The port where the host can be reached.
Type: null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.hostSettings._name_.rsaPublicKey
Desc:
Legacy RSA public key of the host in PEM format, including start and
end markers.

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.hostSettings._name_.settings

Type: attribute set of (boolean or string or signed integer or list of (boolean or string or signed integer))

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.hostSettings._name_.subnets
Desc:
The subnets which this tinc daemon will serve. This will set this
host’s <code class="option">settings.Subnet

Desc: The subnet of this host.

Desc: The prefix length of the subnet.

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.hostSettings._name_.subnets._.weight
Desc: Indicates the priority over identical Subnets owned by different nodes.

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.hosts
Desc:
The name of the host in the network as well as the configuration for that host.
This name should only contain alphanumerics and underscores.
Type: attribute set of strings concatenated with “\n”

Name: services.tinc.networks._name_.interfaceType
Desc: The type of virtual interface used for the network connection.

Desc:
The name of the node which is used as an identifier when communicating

<span class="citerefentry"><span class="refentrytitle">systemd.time

The actual command passed to the
<code class="literal">dsmc

Name: services.tsmBackup.servername
Desc:
Create a systemd system service
<code class="literal">tsm-backup.service

Name: services.tt-rss.enable
Desc: Whether to enable tt-rss.

Name: services.tt-rss.enableGZipOutput
Desc:
Selectively gzip output to improve wire performance. This requires
PHP Zlib extension on the server.
Enabling this can break tt-rss in several httpd/php configurations,
if you experience weird errors and tt-rss failing to start, blank pages
after login, or content encoding errors, disable it.

Name: services.tt-rss.auth.autoCreate
Desc:
Allow authentication modules to auto-create users in tt-rss internal
database when authenticated successfully.

Name: services.tt-rss.auth.autoLogin
Desc:
Automatically login user on remote or other kind of externally supplied
authentication, otherwise redirect to login form as normal.
If set to true, users won’t be able to set application language
and settings profile.

Name: services.tt-rss.database.createLocally
Desc: Create the database and database user locally.

Name: services.tt-rss.database.host
Desc: Host of the database. Leave null to use Unix domain socket.

Name: services.tt-rss.database.name
Desc: Name of the existing database.

Name: services.tt-rss.database.password
Desc: The database user’s password.

Name: services.tt-rss.database.passwordFile
Desc: The database user’s password.

Name: services.tt-rss.database.port
Desc:
The database’s port. If not set, the default ports will be provided (5432
and 3306 for pgsql and mysql respectively).
Type: null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

Name: services.tt-rss.database.type
Desc: Database to store feeds. Supported are pgsql and mysql.

Name: services.tt-rss.database.user
Desc:
The database user. The user must exist and has access to
the specified database.

Name: services.tt-rss.email.digestSubject
Desc: Subject line for email digests.

Name: services.tt-rss.email.fromAddress
Desc:
Address for sending outgoing mail. This applies to password reset
notifications, digest emails and any other mail.

Name: services.tt-rss.email.fromName
Desc:
Name for sending outgoing mail. This applies to password reset
notifications, digest emails and any other mail.

Name: services.tt-rss.email.login
Desc: SMTP authentication login used when sending outgoing mail.

Name: services.tt-rss.email.password
Desc: SMTP authentication password used when sending outgoing mail.

Name: services.tt-rss.email.security
Desc:
Used to select a secure SMTP connection. Allowed values: ssl, tls,
or empty.

Name: services.tt-rss.email.server
Desc:
Hostname:port combination to send outgoing mail. Blank - use system
MTA.

Name: services.tt-rss.extraConfig
Desc: Additional lines to append to <code class="literal">config.php

Name: services.tt-rss.feedCryptKey
Desc:
Key used for encryption of passwords for password-protected feeds
in the database. A string of 24 random characters. If left blank, encryption
is not used. Requires mcrypt functions.
Warning: changing this key will make your stored feed passwords impossible
to decrypt.

Name: services.tt-rss.forceArticlePurge
Desc:
When this option is not 0, users ability to control feed purging
intervals is disabled and all articles (which are not starred)
older than this amount of days are purged.

Name: services.tt-rss.logDestination
Desc:
Log destination to use. Possible values: sql (uses internal logging
you can read in Preferences -> System), syslog - logs to system log.
Setting this to blank uses PHP logging (usually to http server
error.log).

Name: services.tt-rss.phpPackage
Desc: php package to use for php fpm and update daemon.

Name: services.tt-rss.pluginPackages
Desc:
List of plugins to install. The list elements are expected to
be derivations. All elements in this derivation are automatically
copied to the <code class="literal">plugins.local

Name: services.tt-rss.plugins
Desc:
List of plugins to load automatically for all users.
System plugins have to be specified here. Please enable at least one
authentication plugin here (auth_*).
Users may enable other user plugins from Preferences/Plugins but may not
disable plugins specified in this list.
Disabling auth_internal in this list would automatically disable
reset password link on the login form.

Name: services.tt-rss.pool
Desc:
Name of existing phpfpm pool that is used to run web-application.
If not specified a pool will be created automatically with
default values.

Name: services.tt-rss.pubSubHubbub.enable
Desc:
Enable client PubSubHubbub support in tt-rss. When disabled, tt-rss
won’t try to subscribe to PUSH feed updates.

Name: services.tt-rss.pubSubHubbub.hub
Desc:
URL to a PubSubHubbub-compatible hub server. If defined, “Published
articles” generated feed would automatically become PUSH-enabled.

Name: services.tt-rss.registration.enable
Desc:
Allow users to register themselves. Please be aware that allowing
random people to access your tt-rss installation is a security risk
and potentially might lead to data loss or server exploit. Disabled
by default.

Name: services.tt-rss.registration.maxUsers
Desc:
Maximum amount of users which will be allowed to register on this
system. 0 - no limit.

Name: services.tt-rss.registration.notifyAddress
Desc: Email address to send new user notifications to.

Name: services.tt-rss.root
Desc: Root of the application.

Name: services.tt-rss.selfUrlPath
Desc:
Full URL of your tt-rss installation. This should be set to the
location of tt-rss directory, e.g. http://example.org/tt-rss/
You need to set this option correctly otherwise several features
including PUSH, bookmarklets and browser integration will not work properly.

Name: services.tt-rss.sessionCookieLifetime
Desc:
Default lifetime of a session (e.g. login) cookie. In seconds,
0 means cookie will be deleted when browser closes.

Name: services.tt-rss.simpleUpdateMode
Desc:
Enables fallback update mode where tt-rss tries to update feeds in
background while tt-rss is open in your browser.
If you don’t have a lot of feeds and don’t want to or can’t run
background processes while not running tt-rss, this method is generally
viable to keep your feeds up to date.
Still, there are more robust (and recommended) updating methods
available, you can read about them here: <a class="link" href="https://tt-rss.org/wiki/UpdatingFeeds"  target="_top">https://tt-rss.org/wiki/UpdatingFeeds

Name: services.tt-rss.singleUserMode
Desc:
Operate in single user mode, disables all functionality related to
multiple users and authentication. Enabling this assumes you have
your tt-rss directory protected by other means (e.g. http auth).
